{{EngvarB|date=June 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Sir Naim Dangoor | spouse = Renée Dangoor <small>(1947–2008)</small> | children = [[David Dangoor]] and three other sons | image = Naim_Dangoor.jpg | alt = | caption = Naim Dangoor (left) with his friend Ahmed Safwat in 1940s | birth_name = | birth_date = April 1914 | birth_place = [[Baghdad]], [[Ottoman Empire]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2015|11|19|1914|4|1|df=yes}} | death_place = [[London]], United Kingdom | nationality = British | other_names = | occupation = Businessman | known_for = Philanthropy | alma_mater = [[University of London]] | parents = Eliahou Dangoor | relatives = [[Ezra Dangoor|Hakham Ezra Reuben Dangoor]] (grandfather) }} '''Sir Naim Eliahou Dangoor''', [[CBE]] (April 1914 – 19 November 2015) was a British-naturalised Iraqi-born Jewish entrepreneur and philanthropist.
==Early life == He was born in [[Baghdad]] in April 1914, the second of six siblings. His father Eliahou Dangoor (1883–1976) was the world's largest printer of Arabic books,<ref name=Millman>{{cite news|last1=Millman|first1=Joel|title=Iraq's forgotten exiles seek redress|url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/2003/jul/05/iraq.theeditorpressreview|work=The Guardian|accessdate=11 June 2014|date=5 July 2003}}</ref> and his grandfather [[Ezra Dangoor|Hakham Ezra Reuben Dangoor]] was the [[Chief Rabbi]] of Baghdad.<ref>{{Cite news|title = Iraq's forgotten exiles seek redress|url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2003/jul/05/iraq.theeditorpressreview|work = [[The Guardian]]|accessdate = 24 September 2015|first = Joel|last = Millman}}</ref>
In the 1930s, Dangoor made the five-day journey from Baghdad to London, at the age of 17, in order to enroll in an engineering degree at the [[University of London]].<ref name= IPD>{{Cite web|title = Two Centenarians: Iraq’s First Coke Bottler Shares a Birth Year With the Coca-Cola Bottle|url = https://www.einnews.com/pr_news/260467001/two-centenarians-iraq-s-first-coke-bottler-shares-a-birth-year-with-the-coca-cola-bottle|accessdate = 20 November 2015|author = Jamal Booker}}</ref> After graduating he returned to Iraq where he was conscripted into the army and became an officer. It was during his army training that he met his future business partner Ahmed Safwat.<ref name= IPD/>
==Career == Initially on leaving the army he had hoped to become an engineer on the railways, but due to restrictions imposed upon Jews this was not possible, so he and Ahmed, a Muslim, decided to go into business together, setting up Eastern Industries in 1949.
Their first contract was to supply new windows to all Iraqi government buildings, and soon their portfolio grew to include property development and letting.<ref>{{cite web|title = Funding education runs in their family |url = http://www.thejc.com/news/uk-news/131565/funding-education-runs-their-family|work= [[The Jewish Chronicle]]|date = 12 March 2015|accessdate = 24 September 2015}}</ref> In 1950, Eastern industries secured the first contract to bottle [[Coca-Cola]] in Iraq.<ref>{{cite web|title = Two Centenarians: Iraq’s First Coke Bottler Shares a Birth Year With the Coca-Cola Bottle|url = https://www.einnews.com/pr_news/260467001/two-centenarians-iraq-s-first-coke-bottler-shares-a-birth-year-with-the-coca-cola-bottle|accessdate = 24 September 2015|first = IPD|last = Group}}</ref> Alongside Eastern Industries, Dangoor also ran factories producing matches and furniture.
With the founding of the State of Israel and the resulting conflict between Israel and the Arab states, the situation for Jews in the country worsened and in 1959 Dangoor took the difficult decision to take his family out. He continued travelling back and forth for business until 1963, when he decided that the worsening political situation made it too risky for him to return. As a result of laws specific to Jews, he lost his Iraqi citizenship, and his property and business interests were taken by the government.<ref name="promises">{{cite news|last1 = Curtis|first1 = Polly|title = Keeping promises|url = https://www.theguardian.com/education/2004/nov/26/accesstouniversity.highereducation|work = [[The Guardian]]|accessdate = 11 June 2014|date = 26 November 2004}}</ref> He was eventually permitted to settle in the UK where he set about rebuilding his life, setting up a property business that his four sons went on to join.<ref name="University">{{cite web|title = Dr Naim Dangoor|url = http://www.le.ac.uk/ebulletin-archive/ebulletin/news/press-releases/2000-2009/2009/12/portal_factory/NPArticle/nparticle.2009-12-08.0519426930/index.html|publisher = [[University of Leicester]]|accessdate = 11 June 2014}}</ref>
==Personal life==
In November 1947, Dangoor married his cousin,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/12031574/Sir-Naim-Dangoor-businessman-obituary.html|title=Sir Naim Dangoor, businessman - obituary|date=2015-12-03|access-date=2017-12-16|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}}</ref> Renée Dangoor (who had been crowned [[Miss Iraq]] earlier that year).<ref>{{Cite web|title = Dangoor family donates £1.1m to Cancer Research UK|url = http://www.fundraising.co.uk/2010/08/02/dangoor-family-donates-11m-cancer-research-uk/|website = UK Fundraising|accessdate = 24 September 2015}}</ref> They went on to have four sons.
==Philanthropy == In order to preserve the heritage of the community he had left behind, soon after settling in the UK, he founded a community centre in West [[Kensington]] for new Iraqi Jewish immigrants, and in 1971 began editing and publishing ''The Scribe – Journal of Babylonian Jewry'', with 4000 subscribers in 25 countries which continued to be published for 35 years.<ref name="University" /><ref>{{Cite web|title = The Scribe – Journal of Babylonian Jewry|url = http://www.dangoor.com/scribe.html|website = www.dangoor.com|accessdate = 24 September 2015}}</ref>
In 1970 he revived the title of [[Exilarch]] – an ancient title held by the supreme leader of all the Jewish communities in Babylonia, up until the 13th Century.<ref>{{Cite web|title = EXILARCH – Encyclopaedia Iranica|url = http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/exilarch|website = www.iranicaonline.org|accessdate = 24 September 2015|last = electricpulp.com}}</ref>
In 2003 he demanded £12 billion ($20 billion) from Iraq's leaders as compensation for what the Iraqi-Jewish community had lost in Iraq after the [[Second World War]].<ref name=Guardian>{{cite web|last1=Millman|first1=Joel|title=Iraq's forgotten exiles seek redress|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2003/jul/05/iraq.theeditorpressreview|work=The Guardian|accessdate=11 June 2014|date=5 July 2003}}</ref>
As his business in the UK grew, he wanted to give back to the country that had taken him in. In 1980 he set up the Exilarch's Foundation, a charity that has made numerous donations to causes relating to education and health.<ref name = "Funding">{{Cite news|title = Funding education runs in their family |url = http://www.thejc.com/news/uk-news/131565/funding-education-runs-their-family|author= Charlotte Oliver|work = [[The Jewish Chronicle]]|accessdate = 24 September 2015}}</ref>
In 2004 he created the Dangoor Scholarships to help one thousand undergraduate students who had no family history of further education, at the 1994 Group of universities.<ref name = "Funding"/>
A few years later in 2009 he created the Eliahou Dangoor Scholarships, in honour of his father. These were awarded to four thousand undergraduate students, with limited means, studying STEM (science, technology, engineering and maths) subjects.<ref name = "Funding"/>
In the same year Dangoor was made honorary President for the Association of Jewish Academics from Iraq.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://iraqijews.awardspace.com/books.html?|title = Association for Jewish Academics from Iraq|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
The Exilarch's Foundation also sponsors the Westminster Academy in West London, whose pupils hail from over 60 countries, many in the Middle East. Dangoor's family have been closely involved with the running of the school and have seen it go from being issued with an Ofsted 'Notice to Improve' in 2009, to being rated as 'Outstanding' in 2013.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Ofsted {{!}} Westminster Academy|url = http://reports.ofsted.gov.uk/inspection-reports/find-inspection-report/provider/ELS/131262|website = reports.ofsted.gov.uk|accessdate = 24 September 2015}}</ref> Since the Academy opened the number of students achieving five A*-C GCSE grades including both English and Maths has increased from 17% to 70% in 2014.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://westminsteracademy.net/documents/September2010.pdf|title = Westminster Academy Documents|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Ofsted School Data Dashboard for Westminster Academy|url = http://dashboard.ofsted.gov.uk/dash.php?urn=131262|website = dashboard.ofsted.gov.uk|accessdate = 24 September 2015}}</ref>
Dangoor also donated a significant amount to [[Cancer Research UK]] to support their website, in memory of his late wife Renée, who died from breast cancer in 2008.<ref>{{cite web|title=Funding and Partners|url=http://www.cancerresearchuk.org/cancer-help/utilities/about-cancerhelp-uk/funding-and-partners|publisher=[[Cancer Research UK]]|accessdate=11 June 2014}}</ref>
At [[Bar-Ilan University]] in Israel, Dangoor set up the Dangoor Centre for Personalised Medicine in the [[Galilee]], which partners with hospitals to analyse the genetic makeup of individual patients, enabling doctors to implement the most effective treatments.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Bar-Ilan University and the British Friends of Bar-Ilan proudly announce the establishment of the Dangoor Center for Personalised Medicine at the University's School of Medicine in the Galilee – British Friends of Bar-Ilan|url = http://www.bfbiu.org/healthcare/bar-ilan-university-british-friends-bar-ilan-proudly-announce-establishment-dangoor-center-personalised-medicine-universitys-school-medicine-galilee/|accessdate = 2015-09-24}}</ref>
In 2014 he made the largest gift to the Royal Society of Medicine in its history. The donation is being used to help support young people from disadvantaged backgrounds who would like to pursue a career in medicine, as well as supporting the society's post-graduate education provision.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Royal Society of Medicine celebrates £2m donation from Naim Dangoor – RSM press release|url = https://www.rsm.ac.uk/about-us/media-information/2014-media-releases/royal-society-of-medicine-celebrates-2m-donation-from-naim-dangoor.aspx|website = www.rsm.ac.uk|accessdate = 2015-09-24}}</ref>
Dangoor was also the largest private individual donor to the [[Francis Crick Institute]] in London, Europe's largest biomedical research centre.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Europe's superlab: Sir Paul's cathedral|url = http://www.nature.com/news/europe-s-superlab-sir-paul-s-cathedral-1.17827|accessdate = 2015-09-24}}</ref>
Dangoor Walk, a pathway that runs beside the Francis Crick Institute and links Midland Road with Ossulton Street, is named after him.
Through his foundation Dangoor promoted the idea of 'Universal Monotheism' a concept that he believes can bring about unity and create a framework for a global religious ethic. He has sponsored the setting up of a [http://www.monotheism-biu.org/ centre for Universal Monotheism at Bar-Ilan University] from which he received an honorary doctorate in 2006.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Bar Ilan University {{!}} Honorary Doctorate Recipients|url = http://www1.biu.ac.il/indexE.php?id=982&pt=1&pid=35&level=3&cPath=35|website = www1.biu.ac.il|accessdate = 2015-09-24}}</ref>
He made contributions to the [[University of Nanjing]] in China, and had a particular interest in China because his late wife Renée was born and grew up in [[Shanghai]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Which country has 10 Jewish study centres? (And it's not obvious) {{!}} The Jewish Chronicle|url = http://www.thejc.com/news/world-news/52356/which-country-has-10-jewish-study-centres-and-its-not-obvious|website = www.thejc.com|accessdate = 2015-09-24}}</ref> In Nanjing he funded scholarships for the university's Jewish Studies Institute and sponsored an international symposium on monotheism, attended by delegates from all over China, the US, Australia and Israel. In 2011 he was made a consultant professor of the University of Nanjing in recognition of his contributions.
==Honours ==
He received an [[OBE]] in 2006, a [[CBE]] in the 2012 New Year's Honours List, and was made a [[Knight Bachelor]] in the Queen's 2015 birthday honours list.<ref>{{cite news|title = Jewish philanthropists, scientists and artists honoured on New Year List|url = http://www.thejc.com/news/uk-news/61218/jewish-philanthropists-scientists-and-artists-honoured-new-year-list|work=[[The Jewish Chronicle]]|accessdate = 24 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title = Queen's birthday honours: Here's the full list|url = http://metro.co.uk/2015/06/13/queens-birthday-honours-heres-the-full-list-5243692/|work = [[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]|accessdate = 24 September 2015|author = Amy Willis }}</ref> He became the second-oldest person to be knighted, and the oldest to be knighted for the first time – [[Robert Mayer (philanthropist)|Robert Mayer]] was 101 when he was made a Knight Commander of the [[Royal Victorian Order]], but he had already been made a Knight Bachelor at the age of 60.
In 2012 Dangoor was made a fellow of [[Birkbeck College]], part of the [[University of London]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Birkbeck welcomes new Fellows — Birkbeck, University of London|url = http://www.bbk.ac.uk/news/birkbeck-welcomes-new-fellows|website = www.bbk.ac.uk|accessdate = 2015-09-24}}</ref> This was in addition to his honorary fellowship of the Royal Albert Hall of Arts and Sciences, awarded in 2007.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Current supporters — Royal Albert Hall|url = http://www.royalalberthall.com/support/supporters/|website = Royal Albert Hall|accessdate = 2015-09-24}}</ref>
In April 2015, to mark his birthday, Coca-Cola published a piece on the first Coca-Cola bottler of Iraq sharing a centenary with the iconic Coca-Cola bottle.<ref>http://www.coca-colacompany.com/cokebottle100/two-centenarians-iraqs-first-coke-bottler-shares-a-birth-year-with-the-coca-cola-bottle</ref>

{{Infobox person | name = | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = Shin Neung-kyun | native_name = 신능균
申奈舜 | birth_date = 1939 (age 78−79) | birth_place = [[Pyongsan]], [[Hwanghae|Hwanghae Province]], [[Korea under Japanese rule|Japanese Korea]] {{small|(now Pyongsan, [[North Hwanghae]], [[North Korea]])}} | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | residence = [[Seoul]], [[South Korea]] | nationality = South Korean | occupation = Animation director, producer | years_active =1970 - present | website = }} '''Nelson Shin''' (born 1939 in [[Pyongsan]], [[Hwanghae]], [[Korea under Japanese rule|Japanese Korea]]) is an animation director who is the founder and president of [[AKOM|Akom Production Co., Ltd.]], in [[Seoul]], [[South Korea]]. He founded Akom in 1985. In the 1970s, Shin worked as an animator at the [[DePatie-Freleng Enterprises]], where he worked on the ''[[The Pink Panther (film series)|Pink Panther]]'' [[film]]s. While at DFE, he also contributed to the animation of the [[lightsaber]] blades in the original ''[[Star Wars (film)|Star Wars]]''.{{Cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0793802/|title=Nelson Shin|website=IMDb|access-date=2016-07-04}} Much of the [[animation]] Shin's studio has produced has been for American [[television program|television series]]. Some of Akom's credits are: ''[[The Simpsons]]'', ''[[Batman: The Animated Series]]'', ''[[X-Men (TV series)|X-Men]]'', ''[[Invasion America]]'' and ''[[Arthur (TV series)|Arthur]]''. Shin's most well-known accomplishment is his direction of the television series ''[[The Transformers (TV series)|The Transformers]]'' and ''[[The Transformers: The Movie]]''. Shin also directed the first season of the Canadian animated TV series, ''[[Toad Patrol]]''. Beginning in 1999, Shin worked on the animated feature film ''[[Empress Chung]]''. The film was largely animated in [[North Korea]], and in August 2005 became the first movie ever to open simultaneously in North and South Korea. In 2009, he was elected president of the [[International Animated Film Association]], a post he held through 2012.[http://asifa.net/asifa-wp/category/international-news/page/3/ASIFA Board Elects New Officials] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/english/doc/2005-03/05/content_421986.htm "'The Simpsons' Made in South Korea",] ''China Daily'', March 5, 2005. * {{IMDb name|0793802}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Shin, Nelson}} [[Category:1939 births]] [[Category:International Animated Film Association]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:South Korean animators]] [[Category:South Korean businesspeople]] [[Category:Animated film directors]] {{animator-stub}}

[[Image:Kihachiro Okura cropped.jpg|thumb|180px|Ōkura Kihachirō]] {{Japanese name|Ōkura}} ''Incorporates translations from the corresponding Japanese Wikipedia article''
{{nihongo|'''Baron Ōkura Kihachirō'''|大倉 喜八郎||October 23, 1837 – April 5, 1928}} was an [[entrepreneur]] who built up the Ōkura-gumi and founded the giant ''Ōkura [[zaibatsu]]'' (literally financial cliques) and the ''Ōkura Shōgyō Gakkō'' which later became [[Tokyo Keizai University]] in 1949.
== Biography == In contrast to most of the zaibatsu, the Ōkura zaibatsu was founded by someone from the peasant class. Ōkura Kihachirō moved from what is now [[Niigata Prefecture]] on the north shore of [[Honshū]] to [[Edo]] and worked for three years before starting his own grocery store in 1857. After selling groceries for eight years,<ref>[http://www2.sjsu.edu/faculty/watkins/zaibatsu.htm#OKURA Okura zaibatsu]</ref> he became a [[weapons]] dealer during the turbulent years between the arrival of the [[Black Ships]] and the eventual overthrow in 1867 of the [[Tokugawa Shogunate]] and despite being born a peasant, he became an expert in [[Shindō Munen-ryū]]. He became one of the principal business investors of the original [[Imperial Hotel, Tokyo|Imperial Hotel]] completed in 1890.<ref>[http://www.oldtokyo.com/okura.html Okura]</ref>
Kihachiro's son, [[Kishichiro Okura|Kishichirō]], is credited with introducing the [[automobile]] into [[Japan]].
Kihachiro, who made a fortune in his lifetime and lived in [[Toranomon]], was a collector of [[Oriental]] [[antiques]]. In fear of valuable [[Visual arts|artworks]] flowing out to other countries, he built Japan’s first private [[museum]], the [[Ōkura Shukokan]], in 1917 by donating many cultural assets he had collected, the land, and the funds. The 5-story building stood on a property of about 10,000 square meters (2.5 acres), but it was damaged in the [[1923 Great Kantō earthquake]]. The Ōkura Shukokan that now stands adjacent to the Hotel Ōkura was rebuilt in 1928; it was based on a design by [[Itō Chūta]], who is known for his design for [[Tsukiji Honganji]] Temple, and is designated as a cultural asset of Japan. The museum houses 2,000 pieces of Oriental paintings and sculptures, including such national treasures as the wooden statue of [[Samantabhadra]] and 35,000 volumes of [[Chinese literature]].<ref>[http://www.lib.city.minato.tokyo.jp/yukari/e/man-detail.cgi?id=16&CGISESSID=dcd5fd43789c08a3a564dcfaa4f6ce9b Prominent People of Minato City]</ref>
==Honors== ===Japanese=== *Medal of Honor with Yellow Ribbon (6 November 1888) *Medal of Merit of the Japanese Red Cross (November 1898) *Baron (1 December 1915) *Grand Cordon of the [[Order of the Sacred Treasure]] (11 February 1924; Second Class: 26 September 1907) *Grand Cordon of the [[Order of the Rising Sun]] (20 January 1928; Third Class: 3 November 1902; Fourth Class: 28 October 1897)
===Others=== *Second Class, Second Grade of the Imperial Order of the Double Dragon of China (10 February 1912) *Grand Cordon of the Precious Golden Harvest of the [[Republic of China (1912–1949)|Republic of China]] (November 1917; Second Class: 26 January 1915) *Grand Cordon of the Order of the Eight Trigrams of the [[Empire of Korea]] (December 1908) *Grand Cross of the [[Order of Leopold II]] of Belgium (29 October 1926)
== See also == *[[Kishichiro Okura|Ōkura Kishichirō]] *[[Suematsu Kenchō]] *[[Kikuchi Dairoku]] *[[Inagaki Manjirō]] *[[Anglo-Japanese relations]]

{{for|the footballer|Oleg Husyev}} {{Infobox person |name = Oleg Gusev |birth_name = Oleg Andreyevich Gusev |native_name = Оле́г Андре́евич Гу́сев |image = |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1964|04|03}} |birth_place = [[Chelyabinsk]], Russia | residence = [[Ekaterinburg]], Russia |education = {{unbulleted list|[[Ural State Technical University]] (electrical engineering, 1986);|[[Ural State University of Economics]] (finances, 1997)}} |occupation = Chairman of ''Ural Financial Holding'' (several other positions in the past) |net_worth = |website = {{URL|www.oagusev.ru}} }} '''Oleg Andreyevich Gusev''' is a Russian entrepreneur and politician from [[Urals]]. He is currently the head of ''Ural Financial Holding'' enterprise, based in [[Ekaterinburg]], and involved in massive [[land development]] projects and other large businesses.<ref>{{ru icon}} http://www.ufh.ru/holding/governance</ref> Formerly he also was a member of regional government ranking up to vice prime minister.
Nowadays he is also known as arts collector: he possesses paintings of [[Picasso]], [[Chagall]], [[Wassily Kandinsky|Kandinsky]], [[Salvador Dali]], [[Matisse]], [[Warhol]] and others.<ref>{{ru icon}} http://www.e1.ru/news/spool/news_id-428634-section_id-147.html</ref>
== Biography and career == Born in [[Chelyabinsk]] on April 3, 1964.
Graduated from [[Ural State Technical University]] in 1986 as [[electrical engineer]]. In 1997 got a second degree in finances at [[Ural State University of Economics]].
Worked at [[Kalinin Machine-Building Plant]] until early 1990s.<ref>{{ru icon}} http://ekb.dk.ru/wiki/gusev-oleg-andreevich</ref>
In 1993-1998 was participating in creation of, and furtherly headed, the major Zoloto Platina Bank.<ref>https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=22831882</ref>
In the course of the career, for various periods of time, Gusev also held multiple major positions in a number of financial institutions of Urals and Moscow. Particularly, he owned a Chelyabinsk-based bank called Monetny Dom ("coin house"), which he sold by 2010.
=== Ural Financial Holding ===
From early 2000s he began to work for Ural Financial Holding, a major investment enterprise involved in land development,<ref>{{ru icon}} http://ystav.com/v-merii-ekaterinburga-otklonili-proekt-stroitelstva-zhk-glavnyj-prospekt-olega-guseva/</ref> construction, heavy industries, agriculture, researches.
The Ural Financial Holding is supporting Ekaterinburg Opera Theatre and Demidov Science Fund.<ref>{{ru icon}} http://ufh.ru/projects_soc/demidov_science_foundation</ref>
=== Government activities ===
In late 2000s he also worked at Government of [[Sverdlovsk Oblast]] as high-ranking official at several positions up to vice prime minister. While at that position, he was appointed by governor [[Eduard Rossel]] to supervise [[Shanghai Cooperation Organisation]] summit held in Ekaterinburg in 2009.<ref>{{ru icon}} http://ura.ru/articles/1821</ref>
For a period of time, he was a head of the Oblast's major subdivision: [[:ru:Южный управленческий округ|Southern governing district]].
In 2003 Gusev was a candidate for mayoral elections in Ekaterinburg, resulting with 3rd place.<ref>http://ura.ru/articles/100</ref>
He holds several state awards.
== Culture and charities == In 1997 he founded personal charity fund "Good for the people".<ref>{{ru icon}} http://www.oagusev.ru/goodforpeople</ref>
Nowadays he is also known as an arts collector: he possesses paintings of [[Picasso]], [[Chagall]], [[Wassily Kandinsky|Kandinsky]], [[Salvador Dali]], [[Matisse]], [[Warhol]] and others. Sometimes he organizes exhibits of the paintings for public display in Urals.<ref>{{ru icon}} http://www.e1.ru/news/spool/news_id-428634-section_id-147.html</ref>
The Ural Financial Holding is supporting Ekaterinburg Opera Theatre and Demidov Science Fund.<ref>{{ru icon}} http://ufh.ru/projects_soc/demidov_science_foundation</ref>

{{redirect|Open Innovations|the general concept|Open innovation}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2015}} {{Infobox Conferences and Exhibitions | name = Open Innovations Forum and Technology Show | logo = Logo of OI2015.jpg | status = Active | location = Moscow | country = Russia | first = 2012 | genre = [[Innovations]], science, economy | organizer = [[Government of Moscow|Moscow City Government]],
[[Skolkovo Foundation]],
[[Russian Venture Company|RVC]],
[[Vnesheconombank]],
[[Rosnano|RUSNANO]],
[[:ru:Фонд содействия развитию малых форм предприятий в научно-технической сфере|FASIE]] | website = [http://forinnovations.com forinnovations.com] }} '''Open Innovations''' (Forum and Technology Show) is an annual international forum that focuses on new technologies and perspectives of the international cooperation on [[innovation]]s. The focus of Forum is to provide a platform for discussions, interaction and exchange amongst experts in leading edge technologies, scientists, top-managers from Russian and foreign corporations, startups, and state authorities including top public officials. The international exhibition of high-tech achievements is also part of Forum.[http://technomoscow.com/en/press-tsentr/novosti/moscow-international-forum-for-innovative-development-open-innovations-will-hold-its-event-at-techno.php Moscow International Forum for Innovative Development "Open Innovations" will hold its event at Technopilis Moscow] Forum has been held in Moscow since 2012{{cite web|url=http://economy.gov.ru/wps/wcm/connect/fd335b804efc102d87dde7008a11733f/open_innovation_memorandum_booklet_eng.pdf?MOD=AJPERES&CACHEID=fd335b804efc102d87dde7008a11733f|title=International declaration of results achieved at Open Innovations Forum 2012|publisher=Official website of Ministry of Economic Development of the Russian Federation}} under the guidance of the [[Government_of_Russia|Russian Government]] with the support of [[Ministry of Economic Development (Russia)|Ministry of Economic Development of Russia]], [[Government of Moscow|Moscow City Government]] and Russian development institutes: [[Rusnano]], [[Russian Venture Company]], [[Skolkovo Foundation]], [[Vnesheconombank]], Foundation for Assistance to Small Innovative Enterprises in Science and Technology (FASIE).{{cite web|url=http://rustrade.org.uk/eng/?p=1394|title=Open Innovations Forum, Moscow, October 31 – November 2, 2013|date=7 May 2013|publisher=Official website of the Trade Delegation of the Russian Federation in the United Kingdom}} Forum aims to establish itself as a major global innovation platform, capable of predicting the development of the global innovative [[ecosystem]], popularize innovative [[Research and Development]]s, involve top public officials, international corporations and leaders of the innovation community into a dialogue about strategic partnership, and create new tools of international cooperation in innovation.[http://sputniknews.com/voiceofrussia/2013_10_08/Open-Innovations-Forum-is-opportunity-to-strengthen-cooperation-with-Russia-Ambassador-of-Finland-4729/ Open Innovations Forum is 'opportunity to strengthen cooperation with Russia'] ==History== ===Forum 2012=== The first Open Innovations Forum and Open Innovations Expo (an associate exhibition) took place in Moscow between 31 October and 3 November 2012, in [[Expocentre]]. For three days Forum hosted more than 150 events involving 700 speakers from 40 countries.{{cite web|url=http://sputniknews.com/voiceofrussia/2013_10_31/photo-Moscow-hosts-global-Open-Innovations-forum-2703/?slide-1|title=Moscow hosts global Open Innovations forum|publisher=|date=}} Forum was attended by more than 5000 people from 42 regions of Russia and 30 countries around the world.{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/newsroom/dae/itemdetail.cfm?item_id=12036&newsletter_id=126&lang=en|title=A Look at Open Innovations Forum 2012|publisher=Official website of the European Commission}} The event was also broadcast online to a wider audience.{{cite web|url=http://blog.urthecast.com/updates/russias-quest-for-innovation-draws-richard-branson-urthecast/|title=Russia's Quest for Innovation Draws Richard Branson & UrtheCast|author=Theras Wood|publisher=UrtheCast Blog|date=21 June 2013}} With 22 000 sqm of space, Open Innovations Expo hosted more than 500 companies from 16 countries representing more than 1000 of the latest engineering solutions. The exhibition was attended by 10 000 people.[http://rustrade.org.uk/eng/?p=1394 Open Innovations Forum, Moscow, 31 October – 2 November 2013] The organizing [[committee]] of Open Innovations Forum was chaired by [[Vladislav Surkov]].[http://www.venture-news.ru/31930-open-innovations-forum-started-in-moscow.html Open Innovations Forum started in Moscow] [[Dmitry Medvedev]] and other officials participated in the first day [[Plenary session|sessions]] of Forum.[http://www.venture-news.ru/31881-dmitry-medvedev-to-take-part-in-open-innovations-forum.html Dmitry Medvedev to take part in Open Innovations forum][http://www.eu-russia-industrialists.org/news.php Open Innovations Forum is being held in Moscow] [[Deputy prime minister]]s [[Vladislav Surkov]] and [[Arkady Dvorkovich]] gave speeches and represented Russian [[Government agency|government agencies]] at Forum. Heads of Russian state corporations Igor Agamirzyan ([[Russian Venture Company|RVC]]), [[Anatoly Chubais]] ([[Rusnano]]), [[Viktor Vekselberg]] ([[Skolkovo Foundation|Skolkovo]]) also spoke at Forum. Among the many participants were Sir [[Richard Branson]], founder of Virgin Group, Josh Lerner, head of the Entrepreneurial Management unit at [[Harvard Business School]], Alan AtKisson, counselor of the United Nations Commission on Sustainable Development, [[David Yang (entrepreneur)|David Yang]], founder and director of the board of [[ABBYY]], Wim Elfrink, [[Cisco Systems|Cisco's]] executive vice president and CGO for Industry Solutions, [[John Gage]], co-founder of [[Sun Microsystems]], [[Hans Vestberg]], president and CEO of [[Ericsson]] AB.[http://www.gettyimages.com/detail/news-photo/russian-billionaire-viktor-vekselberg-attends-a-session-of-news-photo/155048602 Innovative Development] Forum resulted in more than 20 signed agreements between major Russian and global companies in the field of [[renewable energy]], [[Hi-tech|hi-tech technologies]], education, science, healthcare and [[standardization]].[http://www.themoscowtimes.com/business/article/geography-and-humility-to-fuel-open-innovation-forum/488790.html Geography and Humility to Fuel Open Innovation Forum]//The Moscow Times, 31 October 2013 According to research conducted by the Centre for Studying Regional Problems, Forum rated second in TOP-10 events in the area of innovations in 2012.[http://sputniknews.com/voiceofrussia/2013_10_31/Open-Innovations-Forum-is-success-technologies-spread-in-Russian-regions-Dvorkovich-1758/?slide-1 Open Innovations Forum a success, technology spread in Russian regions] ===Forum 2013=== In 2013, Forum and exhibition took place in Moscow between 31 October and 2 November in [[Crocus City Mall|Crocus Expo International Exhibition Center]]. Forum hosted 75 events including ambassadors and foreign delegations from 22 countries, Russian and foreign ministers, Russian [[innovator]]s from 26 districts of the Russian Federation, and 28 governors of the constituent entities of Russia.[http://marchmontnews.com/Technology-Innovation/Volga/20275-Kendrick-White-Russia-needs-develop-ecosystems-inside-universities.html Kendrick White: "Russia needs to develop ecosystems inside of universities"] Forum was attended by more than 4000 people from 47 countries. The event was covered by 900 representatives of mass media.[http://www.prnewswire.co.uk/news-releases/results-of-the-ii-moscow-international-forum-for-innovative-development-open-innovations-and-open-innovations-expo-2013-231146221.html Results of the II Moscow International Forum for Innovative Development "Open Innovations" and Open Innovations Expo 2013] The organizing committee of Open Innovations Forum was chaired by Deputy Prime Minister [[Arkady Dvorkovich]];[http://globaltechin.com/en/news/225/ Open Innovations Expo 2013] and [[Sergey Sobyanin|Sergei Sobyanin]], the [[mayor of Moscow]], officially opened the Forum.{{cite web|url=http://www.mos.ru/en/authority/activity/innovations/index.php?id_14=27379|title=Moscow hosts 2nd Open Innovations International Forum for Innovative Development|author=|date=|website=|publisher=Official website of the Moscow City Government}} The main topic of Forum in 2013 was "[[Disruptive innovation|Disruption and Innovation]]: Game Changers Powering the Global Market".[http://robohub.org/russia-looks-inward-and-outward-at-moscows-2013-open-innovations-forum/ Russia looks inward and outward at Moscow’s 2013 Open Innovations Forum] This topic was discussed during 3 [[plenary sessions]] and 60 industry sessions with 400 performing speakers. For the first time in 2013, Forum introduced the term, "partner country". [[Finland]] and France became partner countries in 2013. Representing Russia and partner countries respectively were, [[Dmitry Medvedev]], prime-minister of Russia, [[Jyrki Katainen]], prime-minister of Finland, and [[Jean-Marc Ayrault]], prime-minister of France. The three dignitaries took part in Forum where they met with representatives of innovative [[entrepreneurship]] and [[scientific community]], members of "100 innovators" youth program, and participated in the plenary sessions.[http://www.themoscowtimes.com/business/article/forum-shows-russian-ingredients-of-innovation-recipe/488873.html#ixzz2kKkKSGlP/ Forum Shows Russian Ingredients of Innovation Recipe]//The Moscow Times, 1 November 2013 Before the plenary sessions [[Dmitry Medvedev]] has a bilateral meeting with [[Jyrki Katainen]].{{cite web|url=http://government.ru/en/news/7902/ |title=2nd Moscow International Forum, Open Innovations|author=|date=31 October 2013|website=|publisher=Official website of the Russian Government}} Among other invited participants were [[Jason Pontin]], editor-in-chief of [[MIT Technology Review]]; [[Andrea Wong]], president of [[Sony Pictures Entertainment]]; [[Ralph Simon]], CEO of Mobilium Global; [[Duncan Mitchell]], senior vice president of Emerging Markets at [[Cisco]], EVP Innovation and R&D; Gerald Schotman, chief technology officer at [[Royal Dutch Shell]]; Ian Hudson, president of [[DuPont]] Europe, Middle East and Africa and many others.[http://www.themoscowtimes.com/business/article/technology-expert-sees-fear-of-failure-inhibiting-russian-innovation/489029.html#ixzz2kKl70INc Technology Expert Sees Fear of Failure Inhibiting Russian Innovation]//The Moscow Times, 6 November 2013[http://www.euronews.com/2013/11/04/getting-ahead-through-innovation-in-tough-times Getting ahead through innovation in tough times]//Euronews, 04.11.13 Representing government agencies were: [[Vladislav Surkov]], deputy prime-minister; Igor Agamirzyan (CEO, [[Russian Venture Company|RVC]]); [[Anatoly Chubais]] (chairman of board of directors, [[Rusnano]]) and [[Viktor Vekselberg]] (president of [[Skolkovo Foundation|Skolkovo]]).[http://www.thinkrussia.com/business-economy/week-russia-open-innovations-forum This Week in Russia: Open Innovations Forum] There were 530 companies from 9 countries gathered at the integrated Open Innovations Expo exhibition which demonstrated more than 1000 [[Hi-tech|hi-tech developments]] and attracted more than 12 000 people.[http://electronics360.globalspec.com/article/3766/russian-r-d-spreads-its-wings/ Russian R&D Spreads its Wings] The first two days of Forum resulted in the signing of more than 30 agreements on cooperation in [[aerospace]], [[chemistry]], areas in [[IT]], education, ecosystem enhancement, competence and [[business development]]. ===Forum 2014=== In 2014, between 14 and 16 October, Open Innovations Forum and exhibition took place in [[:ru:Технополис «Москва»|Technopolis Moscow]] and attracted more than 15 000 people from 70 countries.[http://www.ait.ac.at/news-events/single-view/?no_cache=1&tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=1919&cHash=f6fefde8d607ff04f1b9900b05410d4b Ait Ehealth expert invited to Open Innovations Forum in Moscow] Forum hosted more than 160 events and welcomed representatives of science, education, [[Technology company|technological companies]], investors and state authorities with more than 800 [[Startup company|startups]] from 19 countries.[http://www.increast.eu/en/1810.php Outcomes of Third Moscow International Forum 'Open Innovations'] The official partner country of the 2014 Forum was the [[People's Republic of China]].[http://www.mos.ru/en/authority/activity/innovations/?id_14=30759 Sergei Sobyanin attends the 3rd Open Innovations Forum] Chinese partners held a special event within Forum called "Dialogue on Innovations: Interaction of [[Innovation#Government policies|Innovation Policies]] of the Partner Countries" where experts outlined trends for further cooperation with Russia.[http://www.rvca.ru/eng/news/2014/10/21/Results-of-III-Moscow-International-Forum-of-Innovative-Development-Open-Innovations Totals of the Third Moscow International Forum on Innovative Development "Open Innovations" and Open Innovations Expo Exhibitions] Forum was personally attended by [[Li Keqiang]], the [[Premier of the People's Republic of China|premier of the state council of the People's Republic of China]].[http://www.ewdn.com/2014/10/21/chinese-premier-reveals-secrets-of-innovative-growth-at-moscow-international-forum/ Chinese premier reveals secrets of innovative growth at Moscow international forum][http://english.cntv.cn/2014/10/14/VIDE1413291843343407.shtml Li Keqiang speaks at Innovations Forum in Moscow] {{Quote|text=''The ability to create, promote and implement innovations is a key factor in competitiveness. The Asia Pacific countries have attained impressive results in the past few years, including China, India, Japan, South Korea, Vietnam, Malaysia and Singapore, which is encouraging talk about the rise of a new global economic pole. Russia is both a European and an Asian country, and we are interested in strengthening our positions in the Pacific region''.{{cite web|url=http://government.ru/en/news/15217/|title=Third Moscow Open Innovations Forum|author=|date=14 October 2014|website=|publisher=Official Website of the Russian Government}}|sign=[[Dmitry Medvedev]]|source=[[Prime Minister of Russia]], 2014}} The main topic of Forum "Creative Destruction: Staying Competitive in the 21st Century" was discussed at more than 70 events.[http://www.rusemb.org.uk/press/1927 Third Moscow Open Innovations Forum] The highlight of the plenary session, "Emerging Global Innovation Map and Ways to Close the Technological Gap between Countries", was the participation of [[Dmitry Medvedev]] and [[Li Keqiang]], [[Head of government|heads of the government]] of Russian and China.[http://www.thinkrussia.com/business-economy/2014-open-innovations-forum-highlighting-emerging-technologies 2014 Open Innovations Forum: Highlighting Emerging Technologies] The session also welcomed [[Andrei Fursenko]], aide to the president of the Russian Federation; [[Dmitry Livanov]], [[Ministry of Education and Science (Russia)|minister of education and science of the Russian Federation]]; [[Denis Manturov]], [[Ministry of Industry and Trade (Russia)|minister of industry and trade]]; [[Sergey Donskoy|Sergei Donskoi]], [[Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment (Russia)|minister of natural resources and environment]]; [[Sergei Sobyanin|Sergey Sobyanin]], [[mayor of Moscow]].[http://www.usue.ru/en/press_centr/news_en/work_en/news-5481.html USUE’s delegation visited the Open Innovations Forum][http://www.mos.ru/en/authority/activity/innovations/?id_14=30759%20/%20http://www.eureca-usrf.net/en/news/news/detail.php?element_id=9359 Sergei Sobyanin attends the 3rd Open Innovations Forum] Among other participants of Open Innovations Forum 2014 were Cabinet members [[Nikolai Nikiforov]] and [[Alexander Galushka]]; heads of companies: [[Viktor Vekselberg]] ([[Skolkovo Foundation|Skolkovo]]), Dmitry Konov ([[Sibur]]), [[Anatoly Chubais]] ([[Rusnano]]), [[Bo Andersson (businessman)|Bo Andersson]] ([[AvtoVAZ]]), Guo Ping ([[Huawei]]), Joe Liu ([[3M]]), Rupert Keeley ([[PayPal]]); scientists: [[Vladimir Fortov]], [[Kurt Wüthrich]] and others.[http://group-eng.cft.ru/Press/Pages/16-10-14.aspx Open Innovations with CFT as a Forum Expert][http://rbth.com/science_and_tech/2014/10/24/innovations_20_the_technology_sector_is_preparing_for_a_rese_40833.html Innovations 2.0: The technology sector is preparing for a reset] The key speakers at Forum were [[Richard J. Roberts|Richard Roberts]] ([[New England Biolabs]]), [[Kurt Wüthrich]] (EZH Zürich), [[Zhores Alferov]], [[Bertrand Piccard]] ([[Solar Impulse]]), and Eckard Foltin ([[Bayer]] MaterialScience). At the end of Forum winners of GenerationS 2014, the federal accelerating competition for technological startups, were announced. The winners were Promobot (Industrial), Kera-Tech (BioTechMed), NanoServ (CleanTech) and VeeRoute (IT).[http://en.inno.msk.ru/pr_pr_gens/generation_s/ Generation S] ===Forum 2015=== In 2015, Forum and exhibition took place in [[Moscow]] on 28 October-November 1 at Pavilion 75, [[VDNKh_(Russia)|VDNH]]. For five days Forum hosted 115 business events involving more than 200 speakers from more than 30 countries. In 2015, the participants of Forum discussed how technologies influence productivity, habitat, education, health and entertainment. The major event of Forum in 2015 was the plenary session "Humanity in the Center of the Technological Revolution" that took place on 28 October. It involved Prime-Ministers of Russia and Serbia – [[Dmitry Medvedev]] and [[Aleksandar Vučić]] as well as economist [[Jeremy Rifkin]], futurist Gerd Leonhard, [[ABBYY]] founder [[David Yang (entrepreneur)|David Yang]]. The session was moderated by [[Mike Butcher]] ([[TechCrunch]] Europe).[http://government.ru/en/news/20290/ Fourth Open Innovations Forum in Moscow] Among the many participants were a [[Nobel Prize]] winning economist [[Nouriel Roubini]], airspace designer [[Burt Rutan]], Jim Morris ([[Pixar]]), [[Aubrey de Grey]] ([[SENS Research Foundation]]), Axel Flaig ([[Airbus]]), Carlo Ratti ([[MIT_Senseable_City_Lab|SENSEable City Lab MIT]]). Representing government agencies were Deputy Prime-Minister of Russia [[Arkady Dvorkovich]], mayor of Moscow [[Sergey Sobyanin]], Cabinet members of [[Russia]], [[India]], [[China]], [[Brazil]], [[Israel]], the [[Republic of South Africa]]. As part of Forum winners of competitions such as Venture Investor, [[:ru:Международная_премия_в_области_нанотехнологий|RUSNANOPRIZE]] 2015, TechUp 2015, Tech in Media 2015 and other were announced. The exhibition part of Forum featured Russian and foreign exhibits including the [[Government_of_Moscow|Moscow City Government]], Russian development institutes, ministries of Russia, Association of Innovative Regions of Russia, [[IBM]], [[Intel]] to name a few.[http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/open-innovations-forum-and-technology-show-2015-started-in-russia-538335491.html Open Innovations Forum and Technology Show 2015 Started in Russia] ==Heads of states and governments who took part in Forum== The table below lists top public officials who participated in the events of Forum as well as events throughout. {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:center; width:90%;" |- ! style="width:15%;"|Country ! style="width:20%;"|Post ! Name ! Photograph ! style="width:15%;"|Years of participation ! style="width:5%;"|Ref. |- |{{flag|Russia}} |[[Prime Minister of the Russian Federation]] |[[Dmitry Medvedev]] |[[File:Dmitry Medvedev official large photo -5.jpg|100px]] |2012, 2013, 2014 |[http://www.eu-russia-industrialists.org/news.php Open Innovations Forum][http://www.themoscowtimes.com/business/article/forum-shows-russian-ingredients-of-innovation-recipe/488873.html#ixzz2kKkKSGlP Forum Shows Russian Ingredients of Innovation Recipe][http://government.ru/en/news/15217/ Third Moscow Open Innovations Forum] |- |{{flag|Finland}} |[[Prime Minister of Finland]] |[[Jyrki Katainen]] |[[File:Jyrki Katainen in June 2013 (cropped).jpg|100px]] |2013 | |- |{{flag|France}} |[[Prime Minister of France]] |[[Jean-Marc Ayrault]] |[[File:Ayrault-111207.JPG|100px]] |2013 | |- |{{flag|China}} |[[Premier of the State Council of the People's Republic of China]] |[[Li Keqiang]] |[[File:Li Keqiang (cropped).jpg|100px]] |2014 |[http://europe.chinadaily.com.cn/world/2014-10/15/content_18739153.htm Premier Li Keqiang promotes innovation in Moscow speech] |- |{{flag|Serbia}} |[[Prime Minister of Serbia]] |[[Aleksandar Vučić]] |[[File:Aleksandar Vučić crop.jpg|100px]] |2015 |[http://government.ru/en/news/20290/ Fourth Open Innovations Forum in Moscow] |} ==Associated events== Apart from plenary sessions, Forum's program includes the exhibition, youth program and cultural program.[http://srb.ved.gov.ru/eng/opportunities/exhibition/?id=7091 «Open Innovations Expo» 2014] ==Exhibition of hi-tech achievements== Open Innovations Forum also hosts the exhibition of hi-tech achievements. Between 2012 and 2014 the original name for the exhibition was Open Innovations Expo. In 2015, the exhibition evolved into Open Innovations Technology Show. ==Youth program== The youth program consists of a number of events for startups arranged as part of Open Innovations Forum. Selection procedures to decide on participants of the youth program are held both in Russia and abroad. During Forum, members of the youth program are offered tours to innovation sites of Moscow, meet with representatives of development institute and investors, participate in lectures and master classes, and get involved in business program of Forum.[http://rbth.com/news/2014/07/10/100_innovators_group_at_the_sco_countries_student_spring_38181.html 100 Innovators Group at the SCO Countries’ Student Spring] == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{Official website|forinnovations.ru/en/}} *[https://www.youtube.com/user/OpenInnovations%20 Official Youtube channel] [[Category:Innovation economics]] [[Category:Innovation organizations]] [[Category:Annual events in Moscow]] [[Category:Recurring events established in 2012]] [[Category:2012 establishments in Russia]]

{{other uses|Mwangi}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Peter Mwangi | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Peter Mwangi | birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1970}} | birth_place = [[Kenya]] | nationality = Kenyan | alma_mater ='''[[University of Nairobi]]'''
{{small|([[Bachelor of Science]] in [[Electrical Engineering]])}}
'''[[Certified Public Accountant|Certified Public Accountants of Kenya]]'''
{{small|([[Certified Public Accountant]])}} | occupation = [[Engineer]], [[Accountant]] & [[Business executive]] | years_active = 2000 – present | home_town = [[Nairobi]] | spouse = | title = [[Managing Director|Group Managing Director]] & [[CEO|Group CEO]]
[[UAP Old Mutual Group]] }} '''Peter King'ori Mwangi''' is an [[electrical engineer]], [[accountant]] and [[business executive]] in [[Kenya]]. He is the current [[Managing Director|Group Managing Director]] and [[CEO|Group Chief Executive Officer]] of the [[UAP Old Mutual Group]], the financial services [[conglomerate (company)|conglomerate]], based in Kenya, with subsidiaries in six African countries.{{cite| accessdate=20 September 2017 |date=20 September 2017 |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=11686576&privcapId=24351707 | title=Executive Profile of Peter King'ori Mwangi, Group CEO & Executive Director, UAP Old Mutual Group | publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg Research]] |author=Bloomberg Research}}{{cite web| date=30 June 2015| accessdate=20 September 2017 |url=http://www.nation.co.ke/business/Former-NSE-boss-Peter-Mwangi-named-CEO-of-UAP-Old-Mutual-/996-2770444-6rujvnz/index.html | title=Former NSE boss Peter Mwangi named CEO of UAP-Old Mutual Group| newspaper=[[Daily Nation]] |location=Nairobi | author=Nation Reporter}} ==Background and education== He was born in present-day [[Nyeri County]], Kenya circa 1970, and attended Kenyan schools for his pre-university education. He obtained a [[Bachelor of Science]] in [[electrical engineering]], from the [[University of Nairobi]], graduating in 1993.{{cite web| url=https://www.standardmedia.co.ke/business/article/2000130546/why-public-is-being-offered-a-piece-of-nse |title=Why public is being offered a piece of Nairobi Securities Exchange |first=Lillian |last=Kiarie |date=5 August 2014 | accessdate=20 September 2017 |newspaper=[[The Standard (Kenya)]] | location=Nairobi}} He is also a [[certified public accountant]] and a [[chartered financial analyst]]. He a member of the [https://www.icpsk.com/ Institute of Certified Public Secretaries of Kenya] (ICPSK). ==Career== He joined the Kenya Air Force (KAF) at the rank of [[Lieutenant]]{{cite web|url=https://www.howwemadeitinafrica.com/meet-the-boss-peter-mwangi-ceo-old-mutual-kenya-2/48297/ |title=Meet the Boss: Peter Mwangi, CEO, Old Mutual Kenya | date=17 April 2015 |accessdate=20 September 2017 | last=Douglas | first=Kate |publisher=''How We Made It In Africa''}} and a job assignment of a Technical Officer. His job included the development of an ICT strategy and the maintenance of the avionic communication systems at the KAF. He worked there for five years, during which time he was promoted to the rank of [[Captain (armed forces)|Captain]].{{cite web| date=4 February 2015 | url=http://www.businessdailyafrica.com/corporate/Old-Mutual-head-Peter-Mwangi-joins-BAT-board/539550-2612818-e7wepsz/index.html |title=Old Mutual head Peter Mwangi joins BAT board | accessdate=20 September 2017 |location=Nairobi |author=BDAfrica Reporter |newspaper=[[Business Daily Africa]] (BDAfrica)}} From 2000 until 2004, he served as [[Company Secretary]] and Investment Manager at [[Industrial and Commercial Development Corporation|ICDC Investment Company Limited]], the precursor to [[Centum Investments]]. Having served as Acting Managing Director from 2004 until December 2004, Peter Mwangi was confirmed as [[Managing Director]] at the company in December 2004. He continued in his role as the [[CEO]], Managing Director and Investment Manager, until 15 October 2008. During his tenure, he company re-branded to "Centum Investment Company Limited'. When he left Centum, he joined the [[Nairobi Securities Exchange]] (NSE), as the Chief Executive Officer in November 2008.{{cite web| url=http://www.africancapitalmarketsnews.com/2431/nairobi-securities-exchange-ceo-peter-mwangi-moves-to-old-mutual-kenya/ | title=Nairobi Securities Exchange CEO Peter Mwangi moves to Old Mutual Kenya |first=Tom | last=Minney | date=10 September 2014 |publisher=African Capital Markets News |accessdate=20 September 2017 |location=Port Louis}} His contract was renewed in 2011 but he had to leave the NSE in 2014, because the law allows for a maximum of two consecutive tree-year terms. During his tenure at NSE, the shares of [[stock]] of the exchange, were demutualised and sold to the public. In October 2014, he was appointed the CEO at Old Mutual Kenya, a subsidiary of [[Old Mutual]], the international financial services conglomerate, with headquarters in London, United Kingdom.{{cite web|date=25 August 2014 | url=http://www.businessdailyafrica.com/Corporate-News/Peter-Mwangi-CEO-Old-Mutual-Kenya/-/539550/2430320/-/124fbx7/-/index.html | title=Peter Mwangi named group CEO of Old Mutual Kenya |accessdate=20 September 2017 | newspaper=[[Business Daily Africa]] (BDAfrica) |author=BDAfrica Reporter | location=Nairobi}} In June 2015, when Old Mutual decided to merge all its businesses in Kenya under one roof, Peter Mwangi was selected to be the Group Chief Executive of UAP Old Mutual Group.{{cite web| url=http://www.businessdailyafrica.com/Corporate-News/Former-NSE-boss-Peter-Mwangi-named-CEO-of-UAP-Old-Mutual-/-/539550/2770582/-/w6tytu/-/index.html | title=Peter Mwangi to head of UAP-Old Mutual merger firm | location=Nairobi |accessdate=20 September 2017 |newspaper=[[Daily Nation]] |author=Nation Reporter}} ==See also== *[[UAP Holdings]] *[[Old Mutual]] *[[Faulu Kenya]] ==Other responsibilities== Peter King'ori Mwangi sits on the boards of the following public and private enterprises: 1. UAP Old Mutual Insurance Sudan Limited. 2. Kisii Bottlers Limited 3. Mount Kenya Bottlers Limited 4. Rift Valley Bottlers Limited 5. Eveready Batteries Limited 6. [[Kenya Wine Agencies Limited|KWAL Holdings Limited]] 7. Central Depository & Settlement Corporation Limited 8. Funguo Investments Limited. 9. British American Tobacco Kenya Limited 10. Wildlife Works Inc. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.uapoldmutual.com/ Website of UAP Old Mutual Group] {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mwangi, Peter}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1970 births]] [[Category:1970s births]] [[Category:Kenyan businesspeople]] [[Category:Kikuyu people]] [[Category:Kenyan accountants]] [[Category:Kenyan engineers]] [[Category:CFA charterholders]] [[Category:University of Nairobi alumni]]

{{Notability|date=April 2011}} {{SCOJCase |Case Name=Bull-dog Sauce Case ([http://www.courts.go.jp/search/jhsp0030?action_id=dspDetail&hanreiSrchKbn=02&hanreiNo=35027&hanreiKbn=01 株主総会決議禁止等仮処分命令申立て却下決定に対する抗告棄却決定に対する許可抗告事件]) |Case Number=2007 No. 30 (平成19(許)30) | Publication Date=August 7, 2007 |Case Reporter=第61巻5号2215頁 |Holding=Discriminatory treatment of some shareholders designed to prevent hostile takeover of a company (in this case the use of a "poison pill") does not necessarily violate the principle of shareholder equality under Japanese statutes. Such decisions must be made by shareholders who deem it in the company's best interest; it cannot be a move made by management to protect itself. |Bench=Second Petty Bench |Chief Justice=Isao Imai ([[:ja:今井功 (裁判官)|今井功]]) |Associate Justice=Osamu Tsuno ([[:ja:津野修|津野修]]), Nakagawa Ryouji ([[:ja:中川了滋|中川了滋]]), Yuuki Furuta ([[:ja:古田佑紀|古田佑紀]]) |Majority Opinion=Unanimous |Concurrence= |Dissent= |Referenced Laws=Company Law Article 109-1; Company Law Article 247-1, 247-2. }}
(An English translation by the Supreme Court of Japan of this case information has not yet been published; however, one will be published in the Journal of Japanese Law, No. 26, 2008. Some information on this page has been translated and will not correspond exactly to the Court's official translation.)
The Bull-dog Sauce Case ([http://www.courts.go.jp/search/jhsp0030?action_id=dspDetail&hanreiSrchKbn=02&hanreiNo=35027&hanreiKbn=01 株主総会決議禁止等仮処分命令申立て却下決定に対する抗告棄却決定に対する許可抗告事件]) is a Supreme Court of Japan case that resulted in a landmark decision regarding hostile takeover defense plans (such as the "[[poison pill]]"). The Court held that such plans do not necessarily violate the principle of shareholder equality under Japanese statutes, even if they result in discriminatory treatment some shareholders; however, such decisions must be made by shareholders themselves, acting in the company's best interest; they cannot be made by management to protect itself. The Bull-dog Sauce case arose from the first use of a poison pill by a Japanese company,<ref name="ssrn.com">Osaki, Sadakazu, "The Bull-Dog Sauce Takeover Defense" at page 2. Nomura Capital Market Review Vol. 10, No. 3 Available at SSRN: http://ssrn.com/abstract=1031031</ref> and resulted in the Supreme Court's first ruling on the subject of takeover defenses.<ref>Osaki, Sadakazu, "The Bull-Dog Sauce Takeover Defense" at page 13. Nomura Capital Market Review Vol. 10, No. 3 Available at SSRN: http://ssrn.com/abstract=1031031 </ref>
==Factual Background==
The Bull-Dog Sauce Co., Ltd. is a Japanese company engaged primarily in the manufacture and sale of food seasonings and sauces; it also owns and leases apartments and buildings.<ref>[http://finance.google.com/finance?q=TYO:2804 BULL-DOG SAUCE CO., LTD.] on Google Finance</ref>
Steel Partners LLC is an American hedge fund with offices in New York and Tokyo.<ref>[http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=23113 Steel Partners LLC] at BusinessWeek.com. The main [http://www.steelpartners.com/ Steel Partners site] provides no information about the company, however the [http://www.spjsf.jp/english.html Steel Partners Japan site] contains ample information about the company's activities in Japanese and English</ref> It has invested in several Japanese companies that manufacture food and beverage products, including Bull-Dog Sauce, [[House Foods]], [[Sapporo Brewery|Sapporo]], and [[Nissin Foods]]; the fund frequently becomes the largest shareholder of a target company and then attempts a takeover or is vocally critical of the company's management.<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/pressRelease/idUS47905+07-Apr-2008+BW20080407 "Steel Partners Submits to House Foods Corp. Suggestions to Improve Corporate Value"], Reuters, 2008-04-07; [http://www.iht.com/articles/2008/02/26/business/sapporo.php "Sapporo rejects takeover bid from Steel Partners"], International Herald Tribune, 2008-02-26; [http://money.aol.com/news/articles/_a/steel-partners-urges-nissin-to-improve/n20080402021409990015 "Steel Partners Urges Nissin to Improve Operations, Efficiency; Offers Recommendations to Enhance Corporate Value"], AOL Money & Finance, 2008-04-02</ref> As of August 2007, Steel Partners held stakes in about 30 Japanese companies.<ref>[http://us.ft.com/ftgateway/superpage.ft?news_id=fto080720072149128123&page=2 "Steel Partners loses final court appeal"], Financial Times, 2007-08-07</ref>
On March 30, 2007, Sapporo Holdings Ltd. shareholders voted two-thirds in favor of [[poison pill]] takeover defense measures in response to a takeover threat from Steel Partners.<ref name="search.japantimes.co.jp">[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nb20070330a1.html "Sapporo investors approve poison pill"], Japan Times, 2007-03-30</ref>
==Legal Background==
===Nippon Broadcasting Case===
The Tokyo District Court and Tokyo High Court rulings both cited the Tokyo High Court's 2005 Nippon Broadcasting Case ruling.<ref>[http://www.courts.go.jp/search/jhsp0030?action_id=dspDetail&hanreiSrchKbn=03&hanreiNo=11&hanreiKbn=02 Full text of the case](in Japanese). For a general overview of the case, see Osaki, Sadakazu, "Regulation of Japan's Capital Markets and the Battle of Control of Nippon Broadcasting System" . Nomura Capital Market Review, Vol. 8, No. 2, pp. 17-24, Summer 2005 Available at SSRN: http://ssrn.com/abstract=872248; or Milhaupt, Curtis J., [http://www.columbialawreview.org/pdf/Milhaupt-Web.pdf "In the Shadow of Delaware? The Rise of Hostile Takeovers in Japan"], 105 Colum. L. Rev. 2171 (2005)</ref> In that case, the High Court ruled that a board of directors was generally ''not'' allowed to issue discriminatory stock warrants to prevent a shareholder from effecting a hostile takeover. However, The High Court noted an important exception: a board of directors ''was'' allowed to discriminate against a shareholder if that shareholder possessed a "abusive motive" (濫用目的). (This language was echoed in the High Court's ruling in the Bull-Dog Sauce Case, in which the High Court found Steel Partners to be an "abusive acquirer" (濫用的買収者);<ref>[http://www.courts.go.jp/search/jhsp0030?action_id=dspDetail&hanreiSrchKbn=01&hanreiNo=34950&hanreiKbn=03 Full text of the Tokyo High Court decision], in Japanese</ref> see below.) The High Court laid out four examples of clearly abusive motives: (1) [[greenmail]]; (2) "scorched earth" tactics (e.g. pillaging intellectual property); (3) aiming to use the target company's assets to pay off the bidding company's debts; (4) aiming to sell off assets to produce a large one-time dividend.<ref>Milhaupt, Curtis J., [http://www.columbialawreview.org/pdf/Milhaupt-Web.pdf "In the Shadow of Delaware? The Rise of Hostile Takeovers in Japan"], 105 Colum. L. Rev. 2171, 2193-4 (2005)</ref>
===Unocal===
''[[Unocal Corp. v. Mesa Petroleum Co.|Unocal v. Mesa Petroleum]]'', 493 A.2d 946 (Del. 1985) was a 1985 Delaware Supreme Court case that established standards for determining the acceptability of takeover defense tactics such as the poison pill.<ref>See generally Gilson, Ronald J., "Unocal Fifteen Year Later (and What We Can Do About It)" . Delaware Journal of Corporate Law, Vol. 26, No. 2, pp. 491-513, Nov. 2001 Available at SSRN: http://ssrn.com/abstract=333041</ref> At the core of the ''Unocal'' decision is the so-called proportionality test: a takeover defense is legitimate if the takeover bid presents a threat to the company, and the defense is proportionate to the threat.<ref>Gilson, Ronald J., "Unocal Fifteen Year Later (and What We Can Do About It)" at page 496. Delaware Journal of Corporate Law, Vol. 26, No. 2, pp. 491-513, Nov. 2001 Available at SSRN: http://ssrn.com/abstract=333041</ref> The Tokyo High Court's ruling in the Nippon Broadcasting Case (see above) has been called a "Unocal rule with Japanese characteristics."<ref name="columbialawreview.org">Milhaupt, Curtis J., [http://www.columbialawreview.org/pdf/Milhaupt-Web.pdf "In the Shadow of Delaware? The Rise of Hostile Takeovers in Japan"] at page 2172, 105 Colum. L. Rev. 2171 (2005)</ref> Indeed, in the Nippon Broadcasting Case, both sides referenced ''Unocal'' in their briefs to the trial court.<ref name="columbialawreview.org"/> The influence of ''Unocal'' was similarly seen in all three courts' rulings in the Bull-Dog Sauce Case <ref name="Osaki, Sadakazu page 14">Osaki, Sadakazu, "The Bull-Dog Sauce Takeover Defense" at page 14. Nomura Capital Market Review Vol. 10, No. 3 Available at SSRN: http://ssrn.com/abstract=1031031</ref>
==History of case==
*May 2007: Steel Partners was the largest shareholder of Bull-Dog Sauce with 10.25% of shares.<ref name="ssrn.com"/> *May 18: Steel Partners initiated a tender offer at ¥1,584 per share with the intention of acquiring 100% of Bull-Dog Sauce stock.<ref name="ssrn.com"/> It was widely suggested that Steel Partners would attempt [[greenmail]]<ref>"However, the court also made an exception when [a poison pill] might be allowed: to fend off a would-be greenmailer—which many in Japan believe Steel Partners to be. (Steel Partners insists it doesn't engage in greenmail...."[http://www.businessweek.com/globalbiz/content/jun2007/gb20070618_584050.htm "Lichtenstein Takes on Japan Inc."], Businessweek, 2007-06-18</ref> or hope for the appearance of a [[White knight (business)|white knight]],<ref name="search.japantimes.co.jp"/> a strategy that had previously proven profitable.<ref>"When Steel Partner's bid for an instant noodle maker was trounced by a white knight, the fund was still able to sell its shares for a 24 per cent premium to the level it was prepared to pay." [http://us.ft.com/ftgateway/superpage.ft?news_id=fto060720071502049270 "Japanese takeovers"], Financial Times, 2007-06-07</ref> *June 7: Bull-Dog Sauce announced that it opposed the tender offer on the grounds that it could possibly harm the common interests of shareholders. At the same time, Bull-Dog Sauce's management proposed changes in the corporate charter and the issuance of stock warrants (the poison pill) at the general shareholders' meeting on 24 June.<ref>Osaki, Sadakazu, "The Bull-Dog Sauce Takeover Defense" at page 2-3. Nomura Capital Market Review Vol. 10, No. 3 Available at SSRN: http://ssrn.com/abstract=1031031</ref> *June 13: Steel Partners responded by seeking an injunction from the Tokyo District Court prohibiting the directors of Bull-Dog Sauce from passing a resolution on stock warrants and blocking issuance of the stock warrants.<ref name="Osaki, Sadakazu page 4">Osaki, Sadakazu, "The Bull-Dog Sauce Takeover Defense" at page 4. Nomura Capital Market Review Vol. 10, No. 3 Available at SSRN: http://ssrn.com/abstract=1031031</ref> *June 15: Steel Partners changed the terms of its tender offer, raising the price to ¥1,700 and pushing the expiration date back from 28 June to 10 August.<ref name="Osaki, Sadakazu page 4"/> *June 19: Steel Partners withdrew the portion of the injunction requesting prohibition of the stock warrant resolution.<ref name="Osaki, Sadakazu page 4"/> *June 24: At the general shareholders' meeting, the Bull-Dog Sauce's proposals to change the corporate charter and issue stock warrants were both approved with 83.4% of the vote.<ref name="Osaki, Sadakazu page 4"/> *June 28: The Tokyo District Court rejected Steel Partners' request for an injunction blocking Bull-Dog Sauce's takeover defense.<ref name="Osaki, Sadakazu page 4"/> *July 9: The Tokyo High Court rejected Steel Partners' appeal, upholding the Tokyo District Court's denial of Steel Partners' injunction request.<ref>Osaki, Sadakazu, "The Bull-Dog Sauce Takeover Defense" at page 7. Nomura Capital Market Review Vol. 10, No. 3 Available at SSRN: http://ssrn.com/abstract=1031031</ref> *August 7: The Supreme Court rejected Steel Partners' appeal, upholding the decisions by the Tokyo District Court and the Tokyo High Court to deny Steel Partners' motions.<ref>Osaki, Sadakazu, "The Bull-Dog Sauce Takeover Defense" at page 12. Nomura Capital Market Review Vol. 10, No. 3 Available at SSRN: http://ssrn.com/abstract=1031031</ref>
==Supreme Court Decision==
===Findings===
The following were among the Supreme Court's findings:<ref>Osaki, Sadakazu, "The Bull-Dog Sauce Takeover Defense" at pages 13-14. Nomura Capital Market Review Vol. 10, No. 3 Available at SSRN: http://ssrn.com/abstract=1031031</ref> # The principle of shareholder equality, as codified in Article 109-1 of the Company Law, requires that a company treat shareholders fairly based on the type and number of shares they hold. However, if there is a risk that the acquisition of management control by a particular shareholder would harm the company's interests or the common interests of shareholders, discriminatory treatment of said shareholder aimed at preventing such acquisition is not a violation of the principle of shareholder equality unless said treatment is unreasonable. # The question of whether the acquisition of management control by a particular shareholder harms the common interests of shareholders "should be decided by the shareholders themselves, to whom the company's interests ultimately inure, and that decision should be respected unless the general shareholders' meeting was procedurally unfair, the facts upon which the decision was predicated prove to be nonexistent or false, or are there is some other important fault that renders the decision unjustified." # Steel Partners had the opportunity to express its opinion at the general shareholders' meeting, and it was able to receive compensation that approximated the value of the stock warrants. As such, the stock warrants were not unreasonable or contrary to the principle of shareholder equality. # A takeover defense plan (such as a poison pill) need not be laid out by management prior to a takeover attempt in order to be fair. # Stock warrants that discriminate against certain shareholders with the aim of supporting the company's management or retaining control in shareholders who support said management is blatantly unfair. The present case does not meet that description, however.
===Validation of Tokyo District Court Ruling===
The Supreme Court's ruling was viewed as a clear expression of preference for the District Court's ruling that the identity of the decisionmaker determines the legitimacy of a takeover defense: shareholders are generally legitimate, whereas managers are generally not.<ref name="Osaki, Sadakazu page 14"/> See points (2) and (5) in above section "Findings". The District Court in turn had relied on the earlier Nippon Broadcasting Case to support these rulings.<ref>Osaki, Sadakazu, "The Bull-Dog Sauce Takeover Defense" at page 5. Nomura Capital Market Review Vol. 10, No. 3 Available at SSRN: http://ssrn.com/abstract=1031031</ref> See above section "Legal Background."
===Rejection of Tokyo High Court Ruling===
The Supreme Court did not adopt the Tokyo High Court's ruling that a discriminatory stock warrant may be used because a hostile bidder is an "abusive acquirer."<ref>Osaki, Sadakazu, "The Bull-Dog Sauce Takeover Defense" at page 15. Nomura Capital Market Review Vol. 10, No. 3 Available at SSRN: http://ssrn.com/abstract=1031031 ; "オしたがって，抗告人関係者が原審のいう濫用的買収者に当たるといえるか否 かにかかわらず，これまで説示した理由により，本件新株予約権無償割当ては，株 主平等の原則の趣旨に反するものではなく，法令等に違反しないというべきであ る。",[http://www.courts.go.jp/search/jhsp0030?action_id=dspDetail&hanreiSrchKbn=02&hanreiNo=35027&hanreiKbn=01 Full text of the Supreme Court Ruling], page 9 (in Japanese)</ref> In reaching this ruling, the High Court had relied on the four examples of "abusive motives" given in the Nippon Broadcasting Case.<ref>Osaki, Sadakazu, "The Bull-Dog Sauce Takeover Defense" at page 9. Nomura Capital Market Review Vol. 10, No. 3 Available at SSRN: http://ssrn.com/abstract=1031031</ref> See above section "Legal Background."
==Impact==
The Supreme Court decision was widely seen as a validation of the legality of the poison pill takeover defense scheme under Japanese law.<ref>See E.G. [https://www.forbes.com/2007/08/08/bulldog-steel-partners-markets-equity-cx_jc_0808markets03.html Japan High Court Keeps Bull-Dog Sauce From Steel Partners' Jaws], Forbes.com, 2007-08-08; [http://us.ft.com/ftgateway/superpage.ft?news_id=fto080720072149128123&page=2 "Steel Partners loses final court appeal"], Financial Times, 2007-08-07</ref>
Although the Supreme Court did not validate the Tokyo High Court's finding that Steel Partners was an "abusive acquirer," the High Court's derogatory label received significant attention in the press and the business community.<ref>"The ruling sent shudders through a foreign investing community fearful that their rights will be compromised if they seek to influence the management of Japanese companies, who have reacted with hostility to efforts by foreigners to bring American-style activism to bear to increase shareholder value."[https://www.forbes.com/2007/07/10/bulldog-steel-ruling-markets-equity-cx_vk_0710markets4.html "Open Wide For Your Poison Pill, Steel Partners"], Forbes.com, 2007-07-10.</ref>
In November 2007, Bull-Dog Sauce estimated a consolidated net loss of 1.7 billion yen for the full year to March, largely as a result of the fight against Steel Partners. Bull-Dog's market capitalization shrank by 45%, from 32.2 billion yen in June 2007.<ref>[https://www.forbes.com/2008/03/10/steel-partners-sapporo-markets-equity-cx_vk_0310markets02.html "Steel Partners Moderates Its Approach To Sapporo"], Forbes.com, 2008-03-10</ref>
On March 28, 2008, Sapporo shareholders voted to renew the company's poison pill takeover defense plan.<ref>[https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601101&sid=a15xWi2z1ajc&refer=japan "Sapporo, Facing Steel Offer, Renews Takeover Defense"], Bloomberg.com, 2008-03-28</ref>
On April 18, 2008, Steel Partners sold its remaining stake in Bull-Dog Sauce.<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/rbssConsumerGoodsAndRetailNews/idUST25213320080418 "Steel Partners exits Japan's Bull-Dog after fight"], Reuters, 2008-04-17</ref>

{{Unreferenced|date=October 2018}} {{Infobox video game |title = School Tycoon |image = School Tycoon Coverart.png |developer = [[Cat Daddy Games]] |publisher = [[Global Star Software]] |designer = |engine = |released = January 15, 2004 |genre = [[Business simulation game]] |modes = [[Single player]] |platforms = [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]] }}
'''''School Tycoon''''' is a [[video game]] developed by [[Cat Daddy Games]] and published by [[Global Star Software]] in 2004. The game was designed to appeal to a younger audience as it is easier and less complicated than other [[business simulation game]]s by removing the spreadsheets and statistics of game management.
== Overview == The game has an overhead view of a farm, city lot, or beach-side lot where a school is to be built. The player places buildings and paths to create the layout of the school. The objectives in the game increase in difficulty as the player progress; an easy objective might be to get a certain number of students into school while a more difficult objective would be to earn a certain amount of money within a time limit. There is also a [[Sandbox (video games)|sandbox]] game mode without specific objectives, giving the player the freedom to build any type of school they desire. The game view can zoom in to select individual students, or zoom out to look at the whole school. The game also has speed controls, to accelerate the pace of events, and has variable difficulty settings. Students in the school can learn ten different subjects. When starting off a school, the player can only afford small classrooms. As money is earned, better and larger classrooms can be built, helping the students to learn more. The player can build academic buildings, sports facilities, entertainment buildings, and an assortment of other structures such as statues, fountains, and food areas. It is also possible to hire teachers and coaches with a variety of different skills.

A '''single customer view''' is an [[Aggregate (data warehouse)|aggregated]], consistent and holistic<ref name="Experian">{{cite web|url=https://www.edq.com/globalassets/uk/product-brochures/single-customer-view-guide.pdf |title=See the benefits of a Single Customer View |publisher=Experian}}</ref> representation of the [[data (computing)|data]] held by an organisation about its customers<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.experian.co.uk/assets/about-us/white-papers/single-customer-view-whitepaper.pdf |title=Exploiting the Single Customer View to Maximise the Value of Customer Relationships|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ardentisys.com/stories/streamlining-customer-data|title=Streamlining Customer Data|website=www.ardentisys.com}}</ref> that can be viewed in one place, such as a single page.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180404073146/https://spotlessdata.com/blog/data-driven-marketing|title=Data-Driven Marketing|website=spotlessdata.com}}</ref> The advantage to an organisation of attaining this unified view comes from the ability it gives to analyse past behaviour in order to better target and personalise future customer interactions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.atominsight.com/about-us/blog/single-customer-view-essential|title=Why a single customer view is essential|publisher=}}</ref> A single customer view is also considered especially relevant where organisations engage with customers through [[multichannel marketing]], since customers expect those interactions to reflect a consistent understanding of their history and preferences.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://econsultancy.com/uk/blog/9612-the-impact-of-a-single-customer-view-on-consumer-behaviour-infographic|title=The impact of a single customer view on consumer behaviour: infographic|publisher=}}</ref> However, some commentators have challenged the idea that a single view of customers across an entire organisation is either natural or meaningful, proposing that the priority should instead be consistency between the multiple views that arise in different contexts.
Where representations of a customer are held in more than one [[data set]], achieving a single customer view can be difficult: firstly because customer identity must be traceable between the records held in those systems, and secondly because anomalies or discrepancies in the customer data must be [[data cleansing|data cleansed]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.atominsight.com/about-us/blog/single-customer-view-hard|title=Why building a single customer view isn’t as easy as you might think|publisher=}}</ref> As such, the acquisition by an organisation of a single customer view is one potential outcome of successful [[master data management]]. Since 31 December, 2010, maintaining a single customer view, and submitting it within 72 hours, has become mandatory for [[financial institution]]s in the [[United Kingdom]] due to new rules introduced by the [[Financial Services Compensation Scheme]].<ref name="Experian"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fscs.org.uk/industry/single-customer-view/|title=Deposit Guarantee Scheme - Customer Review -FSCS|website=www.fscs.org.uk}}</ref>
