{{world|date=August 2017}}'''Social dumping''' is a practice of [[employers]] to use cheaper [[workforce|labour]] than is usually available at their site of production or sale. In the latter case, migrant workers are employed; in the former, production is moved to a low-wage country or area. The company will thus save money and potentially increase its [[profit (economics)|profit]]. Systemic criticism suggests that as a result, governments are tempted to enter a so-called ''social policy regime competition'' by reducing their labour and social standards to ease labour costs on enterprises and to retain business activity within their jurisdiction.
There is a controversy around whether social dumping takes advantage of an [[EU directive]] on internal markets, the [[Bolkestein directive]].
Entities losing from social dumping: * Employees in exporting countries * Child labor in exporting countries * Industry and environment in exporting country * Government in exporting countries * Employees in importing countries * Shareholders of the company in importing countries
Entities gaining from social dumping: * Companies in importing country * Shareholders in importing country * Customers in importing country * Industry in importing market * Employment in exporting country * Government and investment in exporting country
A joint [[NGO]] statement<ref>{{cite web|title=Joint NGO Statement on EU Seasonal Migrant Workers’ Directive|url=http://picum.org/picum.org/uploads/file_/EU%20Seasonal%20Migrant%20Workers%20Joint%20NGO%20Statement%2020%2004%202011.pdf|accessdate=27 August 2012}}</ref> on the EU [[Seasonal industry|Seasonal Migrant]] Workers' Directive<ref>{{cite web|title=Proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the conditions of entry and residence of third-country nationals for the purposes of seasonal employment|url=http://www.statewatch.org/news/2012/mar/eu-council-seasonal-workers-pres-prop-6686-12.pdf|accessdate=27 August 2012}}</ref> also warns against social dumping. The document argues that a vague definition of seasonal work might fail to cover all types of seasonal employment taking place when the Directive exerts its otherwise-welcome protective measures on the labour market.
==See also== *[[Dumping (pricing policy)]] *[[SUTA dumping]]
==References== {{Reflist|1}}
== External links == * [http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/areas/industrialrelations/dictionary/definitions/socialdumping.htm European Union's Eurofound website: Social dumping] *[https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2009/feb/03/trade-unions-lindsey-strikes Cabinet veterans challenge ministers to address 'social dumping'] - The Guardian newspaper (UK) Tuesday 3 February 2009 *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110611044121/http://www.amicustheunion.org/pdf/NECC%20Social%20Dumping%20February%202004.pdf Social-dumping: a crisis in the UK Engineering Construction industry] - [[Amicus]] website *[http://www.gmtdc.com/Training%20Department/newoutlines/Social%20Dumping.pdf Social Dumping Hypothesis Issues and Challenges] GMTDC Business Training & Consultation

{{Icelandic name|Svali}} {{Infobox basketball biography | name = Svali Björgvinsson | image = | caption = | position = [[Guard (basketball)|Guard]] | height_cm = | weight_kg = | league = | team = | number = | nationality = Icelandic | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1967|5|24|mf=y}} | birth_place = | high_school = Nelson | college = | draft_year = | career_start = 1984 | career_end = 1994 | coach_start = 1992 | coach_end = 1999 | years1 = 1984–1985 | team1 = [[Valur (basketball club)|Valur]] | years2 = 1986–1993 | team2 = [[Valur (basketball club)|Valur]] | years3 = 1993–1994 | team3 = [[ÍS (basketball club)|ÍS]] | cyears1 = 1992–1993 | cteam1 = [[Valur (basketball club)|Valur]] (men's) | cyears2 = 1994 | cteam2 = [[Valur (basketball club)|Valur]] (men's) | cyears3 = 1994–1995 | cteam3 = [[Valur (basketball club)|Valur]] (women's) | cyears5 = 1995 | cteam5 = [[Iceland women's national basketball team|Iceland]] (women's) | cyears6 = 1996–1997 | cteam6 = [[KR women's basketball|KR]] (women's) | cyears7 = 1997–1999 | cteam7 = [[Valur (basketball club)|Valur]] (men's) | highlights = | medaltemplates = {{MedalSport | Head Coach for {{ISL}}}} {{MedalSport | [[Iceland women's national basketball team|women's national basketball team]]}} {{MedalCompetition|[[Games of the Small States of Europe]]}} {{MedalSilver|[[Basketball at the 1995 Games of the Small States of Europe|1995 Luxembourg]]|[[Iceland women's national basketball team|Team]]}} }} '''Svali Hrannar Björgvinsson''' (born 24 May 1967) is an Icelandic business man, [[sportscaster]] and former [[basketball]] player.
==Basketball career== ===Club career=== Svali played his first senior game with [[Valur (basketball club)|Valur]] in the [[Úrvalsdeild karla (basketball)|Úrvalsdeild karla]] during the 1984–1985 season. He spent the following season with Nelson High School in the [[United States]]<ref>{{cite news|author1=Þorgrímur Þránsson|title=Svali Björgvinsson, leikmaður með meistaraflokki í körfubolta|url=http://timarit.is/view_page_init.jsp?pageId=4660094&issId=306763&lang=4|accessdate=17 April 2018|work=Valsblaðið|date=1 May 1989|language=Icelandic}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Russ SNyder Invitational|url=http://www.meridianmustangs.org/vimages/shared/vnews/stories/5703cb78ea41f/Russ%20Snyder%20Invite%202016.pdf|website=meridianmustangs.org|accessdate=17 April 2018}}</ref> before returning to Valur in 1986. He played 99 games for Valur in the Úrvalsdeild before retiring.<ref name="visir-msq">{{cite news|author1=Óskar Ófeigur Jónsson|title=Svali raðaði niður þristum í Madison Square Garden|url=http://www.visir.is/g/2014141209758|accessdate=17 April 2018|work=[[Vísir.is]]|date=2 December 2014|language=Icelandic}}</ref>
===National team career=== Svali played two games for the [[Iceland men's national basketball team|Icelandic men's national basketball team]] in 1990.<ref>{{cite news|title=Spennandi mót framundan|url=http://timarit.is/view_page_init.jsp?pageId=3696707|accessdate=17 April 2018|work=[[Fréttablaðið]]|date=8 October 2002|language=Icelandic}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=A-landslið|url=http://kki.is/landslid/karlar/leikjafjoldi/a-landslid/|website=kki.is|publisher=[[Icelandic Basketball Federation]]|accessdate=17 April 2018|language=Icelandic}}</ref>
==Coaching career== Svali coached Valur men's team for several seasons in Úrvalsdeild karla while also coaching Valur women's team and [[KR women's basketball|KR]] women's team for one season each in [[Úrvalsdeild kvenna (basketball)|Úrvalsdeild kvenna]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Svali ræddi við Hauka|url=http://timarit.is/view_page_init.jsp?pageId=1933933|accessdate=17 April 2018|work=[[Morgunblaðið]]|date=30 April 1999|language=Icelandic}}</ref>
He was the head coach of the [[Iceland women's national basketball team|Icelandic women's national basketball team]] during the [[Basketball at the 1995 Games of the Small States of Europe|1995 Games of the Small States of Europe]] in [[Luxembourg]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Svali búinn að velja|url=https://www.mbl.is/greinasafn/grein/203693/|accessdate=17 April 2018|work=[[Morgunblaðið]]|date=27 May 1995|language=Icelandic}}</ref>
==Broadcasting career== Svali works as a play-by-play broadcaster of [[Úrvalsdeild karla (basketball)|Úrvalsdeild karla]] games at [[Stöð 2 Sport]]<ref name="visir-msq"/> and is well known for his lively phrases.<ref>{{cite news|author1=Tómas Þór Þórðarson|title=Sjáðu allar galdrakörfur Bonneau í lýsingu Svala: "Hann er bara skyr og massi"|url=http://www.visir.is/g/2015150329147|accessdate=17 April 2018|work=[[Vísir.is]]|date=27 March 2015|language=Icelandic}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=ÁHUGAVERT Tólf bestu lýsingar Svala í úrslitakeppninni: "Þetta er eins og innbrotsþjófur með hóstakast"|url=http://nutiminn.is/tolf-bestu-lysingar-svala-i-urslitakeppninni-thetta-er-eins-og-innbrotsthjofur-med-hostakast/|accessdate=17 April 2018|work=Nútíminn|date=29 April 2015|language=Icelandic}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author1=Anton Ingi Leifsson|title=Þetta er lögreglumál! - Arnar og Svali fara á kostum|url=http://www.visir.is/g/2015150409772/thetta-er-logreglumal-arnar-og-svali-fara-a-kostum|accessdate=17 April 2018|work=[[Vísir.is]]|date=3 April 2015|language=Icelandic}}</ref>
==Outside of basketball== Svali worked at [[Kaupþing]] from 2003 until 2009 when he joined [[Icelandair]].<ref>{{cite news|author1=Stefán Ó. Jónsson|title=Svali Björgvins hættir hjá Icelandair|url=http://www.visir.is/g/2018180109626|accessdate=17 April 2018|work=[[Vísir.is]]|date=4 January 2018|language=Icelandic}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author1=Kristín Sigurðardóttir|title=Háskólagráðan ofmetin|url=http://www.ruv.is/frett/haskolagradan-ofmetin|accessdate=17 April 2018|work=[[RÚV]]|date=25 January 2016|language=Icelandic}}</ref> In 2018, he joined [[Sjóvá]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Svali stýrir stefnumótun hjá Sjóvá|url=https://www.mbl.is/vidskipti/frettir/2018/02/23/svali_styrir_stefnumotun_hja_sjova/|accessdate=17 April 2018|work=[[Morgunblaðið]]|date=23 February 2018|language=Icelandic}}</ref>

[[Vodafone]] CEO |education =[[Bocconi University]]
[[Harvard University]] |networth = |salary = £8,927,000 (2014, total compensation){{cite web|title=Executive Profile: Vittorio A. Colao|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=2008054&ticker=VOD|website=Bloomberg|accessdate=26 March 2015}} | title = CEO, [[Vodafone]] | term = July 2008 - October 2018 | predecessor = [[Arun Sarin]] | successor = [[Nick Read]] |spouse = Married 1992 |children = 2 |website = [http://www.vodafone.com/content/index/about/exco.html Bio at Vodafone] |footnotes = }} '''Vittorio Amedeo Colao''' (born 3 October 1961) is an Italian businessman, chief executive officer at [[Vodafone Group]]. ==Early life== The son of an officer in the [[Carabinieri]], he was born in [[Brescia]].{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2008/may/27/vodafonegroup.mobilephones|title=Vittorio Colao: from Brescia to the top of Vodafone|author=Wearden, Graeme|publisher=The Guardian|date=2008-05-27|accessdate=2008-05-27}} He received a business degree from [[Bocconi University]] and an MBA from the [[Harvard Business School]].{{cite journal |title=Vittorio Colao|url=https://www.alumni.hbs.edu/stories/Pages/story-bulletin.aspx?num=4284|date = 1 December 2014}} ==Career== He started his career at [[investment banker|investment bank]] [[Morgan Stanley]] in London.{{cite web|url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/industry_sectors/telecoms/article4011893.ece|title=Who is Colao?|author=Lindsay, Robert|publisher=The Times|date=2008-05-27|accessdate=2008-05-27 | location=London}} He joined the [[Milan]] office of [[McKinsey & Company|McKinsey & Co]] in 1986, where as a Partner he worked on media, telecommunications and industrial goods sectors and was responsible for office recruitment. In 1996 he joined [[Omnitel Pronto Italia]], rising to chief operating officer before its take over to become [[Vodafone Italy]]. He became regional CEO, Southern Europe in 2001 and joined the main board in 2002. After missing out on the CEO's job, taken by his friend [[Arun Sarin]], and having a purchase of a Bulgarian mobile company blocked, he left Vodafone for Italian publishing company [[RCS MediaGroup]], where he became CEO in July 2004.{{cite web|url=https://alumni.mckinsey.com/alumni/default/public/content/jsp/alumni_news/20040623_Vittorio_Colao.jsp|title=Vittorio Colao (86-96 MIL) New CEO of RCS MediaGroup|publisher=McKinsey & Co|date=2004-06-23|accessdate=2008-05-27}} After shareholder criticism of the publishing group's strategy and governance, he resigned from RCS MediaGroup following the company's board meeting in September,{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/business/feeds/afx/2006/07/21/afx2894859.html|title=RCS CEO resigns after shareholder criticisms|publisher=Forbes/AFX News|date=2006-07-21|accessdate=2008-05-27}} rejoining Vodafone in October 2006 as CEO Europe and succeeding [[Julian Horn-Smith|Sir Julian Horn-Smith]] as deputy CEO.{{cite web|url=http://www.cellular-news.com/story/19148.php|title=Vodafone Names Vittorio Colao European Region Ceo|publisher=Dow Jones|date=2006-09-06|accessdate=2008-05-27}} Commenting to the Italian press in 2007 that he had no interest in taking the CEO's job at [[Telecom Italia]],{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/money/main.jhtml?xml=/money/2008/05/27/ccsarin327.xml|title=Vittorio Colao fends off Vodafone competition|author=Blackden, Richard|publisher=The Telegraph|date=2008-05-27|accessdate=2008-05-27}} Colao succeeded Vodafone CEO [[Arun Sarin]] on 29 July 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.vodafone.com/start/media_relations/news/group_press_releases/2007/vodafone_announces6.html|title=Vodafone Announces New Chief Executive|publisher=Vodafone|date=2008-05-27|accessdate=2008-05-27}}. In 2015, he was appointed as a non-executive director of [[Unilever]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.unilever.com/about/who-we-are/our-leadership/Vittorio-Colao.html|title=Vittorio Colao|website=Unilever global company website|language=en|access-date=2017-03-23}}{{Additional citation needed|date=March 2017}} In May 2018, he announced that he would step down as Vodafone CEO effective October 2018, and will be succeeded by the finance director [[Nick Read]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/business-44121061|title=Vodafone boss Vittorio Colao to step down|publisher=BBC News|language=en|access-date=2018-05-16}} ==Personal life== Married in 1992, his wife and two children reside with him in England. Colao is a reserve officer in the [[Carabinieri]]. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.vodafone.com/content/index/about/exco.html Bio at Vodafone Group] * [https://www.forbes.com/finance/mktguideapps/personinfo/FromPersonIdPersonTearsheet.jhtml?passedPersonId=1119026 Bio at Forbes.com] * [https://www.bloomberg.com/profiles/people/1712423-vittorio-amedeo-colao Bio at Bloomberg.com] {{Vodafone}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Colao, Vittoro Amedeo}} [[Category:1961 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Brescia]] [[Category:Bocconi University alumni]] [[Category:Harvard Business School alumni]] [[Category:Italian businesspeople]] [[Category:Vodafone people]] [[Category:McKinsey & Company people]] {{italy-business-bio-stub}}

(2) Rose Hellewell |relations = |children = Five |alma_mater = |profession = |religion = |signature = }} '''Sir William Appleton''' {{post-nominals|country=NZL|KStJg|size=85%}} (3 September 1889 – 22 October 1958) was a New Zealand local body politician, advertising agent and leading company director. He was [[Mayor of Wellington City|Mayor of Wellington]] for two terms from 1944 to 1950 after serving as a city councillor from 1931 to 1944. He was [[Knight Bachelor|knighted]] in [[1950 Birthday Honours|1950]]. ==Biography== ===Early life and career=== Appleton was born in [[Alexandra, New Zealand|Alexandra]] in [[Central Otago]] in 1889, the eldest of nine children. His parents were Yorkshireman Edwin Appleton and his Scottish wife, Margaret Bruce. The Appleton family briefly moved to [[Gisborne, New Zealand|Gisborne]] in 1904 but was back in Alexandra in the following year. Appleton, left by the postmaster in charge of the local post office as a teenager, did some bookkeeping for local businesses. In October 1906, aged 17, he was appointed a cadet in the accountancy department of the General Post Office at [[Wellington]]. In 1909 he passed his accountancy exams. He left the Post and Telegraph Department, then still a centre of modern communications technology, and in April 1910 joined advertising agent Charles Haines and Co. Haines had founded his business, the country's first [[advertising agency]], in Wellington in 1891.[https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/EP19100423.2.24 ''The Evening Post''] page 5, 23 April 1910[https://teara.govt.nz/en/advertising/page-2 ''Te Ara''] Advertising agencies, 1891–1970 Will married Mary Helen (Nell) Munro in March 1913. They were to have a daughter and two sons. By the time of the [[first world war]] 25-year-old Will Appleton was manager of Charles Haines.[https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/DOM19150123.2.20 ''The Evening Post''] page 6, 23 January 1915 He was appointed managing director in 1918. Nell died in 1918's influenza epidemic. The following year he married Rose Hellewell and they had a daughter and two sons. Meanwhile Appleton maintained his local body interests serving on the Wellington Hospital Board from 1923. In 1931 he successfully stood for the Wellington City Council. Then in 1932 he sold his interest in Charles Haines to his former partners, accepted directorships in many major listed companies and devoted himself to politics.[https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/EP19320630.2.107 ''The Evening Post] page 12, 30 June 1932 ===Political career=== ====Local politics==== [[File:Cecil Wood, Rt Rev H St Barbe Holland and Will Appleton.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Cathedral architect, Bishop and (Presbyterian) mayor. From left: [[Cecil Wood (architect)|Cecil Wood]], [[St Barbe Holland|Herbert St Barbe Holland]] and Appleton discussing plans for the new [[Saint Paul's Cathedral, Wellington|Wellington Cathedral]] in 1945]] After moving to Wellington, Appleton was elected to the [[Borough of Onslow|Onslow Borough Council]] in 1915 where he led a successful campaign for amalgamation with Wellington in order to gain an integrated water and drainage system. In 1923 he was elected to the Wellington Hospital Board on a [[Civic League]] ticket and remained a member until 1929. In [[Wellington City mayoral election, 1931|1931]] Appleton was elected to the [[Wellington City Council]] where he became an effective and popular councillor renowned as being friendly, approachable and possessing a "chuckling" sense of humour. He became chair of the Works Committee and oversaw the introduction of a system of refuse disposal to converted gullies into sports grounds including Appleton Park, which was named after him. In [[Wellington City mayoral election, 1944|1944]] Appleton challenged [[Thomas Hislop (mayor)|Thomas Hislop]] for the Citizens' nomination to stand for mayor. Appleton claimed he would stand as an independent should he not be granted the candidacy. Declining arbitration, Appleton got his wish when Hislop (albeit reluctantly) agreed to stand aside in the interests of unity.{{sfn|Betts|1970|pp=180}} Appleton was elected with a huge majority and was later re-elected for a second term in [[Wellington City mayoral election, 1947|1947]] by a lower margin before retiring in 1950.{{cite news |url=https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/EP19440529.2.84.4 |work =Evening Post |page=11 |title=Mr. Appleton Mayor|date=29 May 1944 |accessdate= 28 October 2016 | volume=CXXXVII | issue=125 }}{{cite report |last=Norrie |first=J |date=1 December 1947 |title=Declaration of Election Results |url= |publisher=[[Wellington City Council]] |page= |docket= |access-date=24 November 2016 }} In a [[List of by-elections to the Wellington City Council#1955 by-election|1955 by-election]] Appleton was invited by the Citizens' Association to stand once again for the City Council, though he declined to re-enter local politics.{{cite news |title=Interest Aroused in Wellington City Council By-Election |newspaper=[[The Evening Post (New Zealand)|The Evening Post]] |date=6 December 1954 }} Appleton served for 21 years as a member of the [[Wellington Harbour Board]], representing Wellington City, and was its chairman for 3 of those years (1954–57).{{cite book |first=David |last=Johnson |chapter=Members and Officers of the Wellington Harbour Board, Appendix 1 |page=475 |title=Wellington Harbour |publisher=Wellington Maritime Museum Trust |year=1996 |isbn=0958349800}} ====National politics==== He unsuccessfully stood for Parliament several times. In the {{NZ election link|1931}}, he contested the {{NZ electorate link|Wellington South}} electorate for the [[United Party (New Zealand)|United Party]] and was beaten by [[Robert McKeen]].{{cite book |title=The General Election, 1931 |year=1932 |publisher=Government Printer |url= http://atojs.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/atojs?a=d&d=AJHR1932-I-II.2.3.2.31 |page=5 |accessdate=2 November 2014}} In the {{NZ election link|1935}}, he contested the {{NZ electorate link|Otaki}} electorate as an independent candidate and came third.{{cite news |title=Mr. Appleton's Candidature |url= http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=EP19351021.2.134 |accessdate=28 March 2014 |newspaper=[[The Evening Post (New Zealand)|The Evening Post]] |date=21 October 1935 |volume=CXX |issue=97 |page=11}}{{cite news |title=Otaki Seat |url= http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=EP19351021.2.134 |accessdate=28 March 2014 |newspaper=[[The Evening Post (New Zealand)|The Evening Post]] |date=2 September 1935 |volume=CXX |issue=55 |page=10}}{{cite news |title=How the votes were cast |url= http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=EP19351128.2.53.2 |accessdate=16 November 2013 |newspaper=[[The Evening Post (New Zealand)|The Evening Post]] |date=28 November 1935 |volume=CXX |issue=130 |page=8}} In the {{NZ election link|1938}} standing for the [[New Zealand National Party|National Party]] in the {{NZ electorate link|Wellington Central}} electorate, he came second but was beaten by [[New Zealand Labour Party|Labour]]'s [[Peter Fraser (New Zealand politician)|Peter Fraser]].{{cite web |title = The General Election, 1938 |url = http://atojs.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/atojs?a=d&d=AJHR1939-I.2.3.2.36 |publisher = National Library |accessdate = 8 February 2012 |pages = 1–6 |year = 1939}} He was to stand against Fraser again in the cancelled 1941 general election. In the {{NZ election link|1943}}, Appleton was again unsuccessful but came second and greatly reduced Fraser's majority.{{cite web |title=The General Election, 1943 |url= http://www.atojs.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/atojs?a=d&cl=search&d=AJHR1944-I.2.2.5.37 |publisher=[[National Library of New Zealand|National Library]] |accessdate=2 January 2014 |pages=1–12 |year=1944}} He did not contest the {{NZ election link|1946}}, but stood for a third time in Wellington Central in {{NZ election link|1949}} against Fraser's successor [[Charles Henry Chapman (politician)|Charles Henry Chapman]], but was again defeated.{{cite web |title=The General Election, 1949 |url= http://atojs.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/atojs?a=d&d=AJHR1950-I.2.3.2.43 |publisher=[[National Library of New Zealand|National Library]] |accessdate=3 January 2014 |pages=1–5, 8 |year=1950}} ===Later life and death=== Appleton was president of the [[Wellington Rugby League|Wellington Rugby Football League]] from 1940 to 1958 and presented the Appleton Shield, which is used to this day as the premier club trophy.{{DNZB|Buchan|Allison|4a19|Appleton, William |10 January 2012}} In the [[1950 Birthday Honours (New Zealand)|1950 King's Birthday Honours]], Appleton was appointed a [[Knight Bachelor]], in recognition of his service as mayor of Wellington.{{London Gazette |issue=38931 |date=8 June 1950 |page=2813 |supp=y }} In 1953 he was made a [[Venerable Order of Saint John|Knight of Grace of the Order of St John]].{{London Gazette |issue=39743 |date=2 January 1953 |page=94 }} Appleton died of cancer in Bowen Hospital, Wellington, on 22 October 1958. {{multiple issues| {{Update|inaccurate=yes|date=April 2010}} {{refimprove|date=January 2009}} }} {{Infobox Airline | airline = Xpressair | image = XpressAir logo.png | image_size = 216 | IATA = XN | ICAO = XAR | callsign = XPRESS | founded = 2003 | commenced = | ceased = | hubs = * [[Bandung]] - [[Husein Sastranegara International Airport]] * [[Tanjung Pinang]] - [[Raja Haji Fisabilillah International Airport]] | focus_cities = | frequent_flyer = | lounge = | alliance = | subsidiaries = | fleet_size = 11 | destinations = 11 | parent = | company_slogan = Terbanglah Indonesia (Fly, Indonesia) | headquarters = [[Indonesia]] | key_people = | website = http://www.xpressair.co.id |aoc=|num_employees=}} [[File:Bandara Sultan Babulah Ternate - panoramio - Marcky Bolung.jpg|thumb|Xpress Air planes at [[Sultan Babullah Airport]]]] '''Xpress Air''' established itself as a Domestic Regular Airline that offers direct flights to the Eastern parts of Indonesia, with its first leap in the year 2005 and from 2014 served international routes to [[Malaysia]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2014/06/11/express-air-link-pontianak-and-johor-bahru-weekend.html |title=Express Air to link Pontianak and Johor Bahru this weekend |date=June 11, 2014}}</ref> Beginning with its two Boeing 737s, Xpress Air became the first privately owned, scheduled airline that connects Jakarta to 24 domestic destinations like Makassar (formerly known as Ujung Pandang), Ternate, Sorong, Manokwari, and Jayapura. Makassar serves as a main hub for all flights coming from Java islands to the Eastern cities of Indonesia, while Sorong serves as a second hub in Papua, connecting remote places surrounding West Papua Area.
Xpress Air is supported by PT Aero Nusantara Indonesia (ANI), a trusted Aircraft Maintenance Provider, ensuring a pledge to safety, quality and security to its passengers.
Express Air is listed in category 1 by Indonesian [[Civil Aviation Authority]] for airline safety quality.<ref>http://hubud.dephub.go.id/?en+news+detail+1464+8</ref>
==History== Express Air begun commercial operations between Jayapura and Jakarta on June 23, 2003. Since then, the airline has grown to become one of the major airlines in Eastern Indonesia. Xpress Air is currently in the process of a major fleet expansion to serve more numbers of destinations along West-East Papua axis, Sulawesi, Maluku, and Nusa Tenggara region. The vision to also offer routes to the western regions has been met as Xpress Air has begun connecting people to Yogyakarta, Surabaya, Kalimantan, Pontianak and more.
The year 2012 embarked a new journey for Xpress Air with a new branding name (from Express Air to Xpress Air to represent a more modern and customer-friendly airline), a new strategy and a fresh new slogan "Terbanglah Indonesia", holding close to its heart the same culture and tradition of a friendly airline with new, modern advancements and motivation

{{nihongo|'''Yoji Akao'''|赤尾 洋二|Akao Yōji|1928 – October 24, 2016}} is a [[Japan]]ese planning specialist recognized as the developer of [[Hoshin Kanri]] (a [[strategic planning]] methodology). With the late [[Shigeru Mizuno]], he developed [[Quality Function Deployment]] (a group [[decision making]] technique). Akao and Mizuno also co-founded the Quality Function Deployment Institute: a non-profit organization dedicated to dissemination and advancement of QFD.<ref>[http://www.qfdi.org/ QFD Institute. Home page of Quality Function Deployment Institute. The Official Source for QFD<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
Akao received a Ph.D. in 1964 from the [[Tokyo Institute of Technology]].<ref>[http://www.productivitypress.com/contributorinfo.cfm?ContribID=124 Productivity Press] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061114005820/http://www.productivitypress.com/contributorinfo.cfm?ContribID=124 |date=November 14, 2006 }}</ref>
==Books== Akao authored or co-authored several books:
* Quality Function Deployment: Integrating Customer Requirements Into Product Design (1991) * Hoshin Kanri: Policy Deployment for Successful TQM (Corporate Leadership) (1990) * QFD: The Customer Driven Approach to Quality Planning and Deployment (co-authored with Shigeru Mizuno) (1994)
==Awards== * Deming Prize: 1978 * Quality Control Literature Prize: 1960 and 1978
